For a game converted from the PSvita, Its pretty fun. I like the nice balance from story to combat that you maneuver through. My laptop can't handle crazy graphics so the PS2 style graphics are perfect for me. I'd have appreciated a pinch more detail and variety in the sprites but it is overshadowed by the lengthy and abundance of searching and dialog that is always changing around. 38908948.review:
Man, I started this game, not expecting much; got it on sale. Just wanted to pass the time. But great mechanics, solid story. Beginning was slow (to be expected since it introduces you to all the mechanics slowly), but once I got into it, I was so absorbed into all the characters and the storyline. Not too difficult, but still challenging.

There's lots of hidden bits that you really have to go out of your way to find if you want to be a completionist. You HAVE to replay it as well in order to get all the achievements. I probably won't replay it, I just like to play games for the story, but well worth the money I put into it.

I should, however, mention that I was playing with an Xbox One controller. I've played similar games but using keyboard and mouse and it's just tricky to get to grips with. I would highly recommend a controller.

tl;dr:

+ Story and character are top-notch.
+ Mechanics are pretty easy to get the hang of.
+ Difficulty remains challenging yet feasible.
+ Decent hours.

- Requires a controller for efficient gameplay (imo).
- No real replayability other than for achievements.
- Trails of Cold Steel 2 isn't out yet ㅠㅠ.

38904255.review:
It's bloody fantastic.

I kind of want to say I was disappointed by the ending, but it seems silly to say that since you're more or less meant to be - it's supposed to set you up for the next game, as you can imagine.

There are maybe a few "Bracer quests" (so to speak) that could be called superfluous or tedious.

But these are the minorest of minor complaints.  It's phenomenal, I'd call it my favorite port of 2017.

38797604.review:
This game deserves to be in the pantheon of incredible jRPGs along with the Trails in the Sky games, Persona games, Earthbound, and others. I love the structure of it, how slow it is yet how interesting it always continues to be, I was never bored throughout the 90ish hours I played the game which is astounding. 

Every character has their moment, through their relationship with the main character or with each other. This game does social links better than the modern Persona games ever did and it weaves them brilliantly into the main story. The combat is always entertaining (even when you absolutely break it with powerful quartz and abilities towards the end of the game). The cliffhanger ending isn't quite as good as the first Trails in the Sky game, but it makes me super hype for the sequel to come out on steam. I kind of wish it didn't look like a PS2 game, but even with its rudimentary visuals it shows off some impressive world design and cities throughout.

Just a note regarding how I played the game: I've heard the dub in this game is quite good, but I played it with modded files to use JP voice acting since that is how I prefer to play these type of games. This worked fine, the only lines that are missing translation are the battle voices  (including the very short dialog from the bosses as you beat them up). Unfortunately I also had some performance issues that seemed to be related to the fact that running the game in fullscreen puts it in borderless fullscreen. I've had this issue in other games where running in window mode kinda messes up the framerate, which is why I run games in exclusive fullscreen. Turns out the only way to run this game in exclusive fullscreen is to edit the xml file directly, and when you do that it doesn't have any alt-tab support or the game crashes. Other than the alt-tab issue, running the game in exclusive fullscreen fixed my framerate issue completely.

38733210.review:
The first game in the series for Trails of Cold Steel, part of the larger universe of "The Legend of Heroes". This game is a PC port of the original game launched back in 2013. 

When i initially saw this game on steam in August 2017, I was interested. The second the game release  I brought it, and never regretted it. This is my second foray into JRPG, my first being my aborted attempted at one of the Tales Of series, that had real time battle sequences, apart from the turn based the majority of JRPG's use. 

I personally, now after completing my first run through of this game 70 hours in, prefer the turn base. 

The story commences, and you are immeditately hit with a large group that will evantually grow into your team. Each, yes, it could be said with its "torpe" characters, and some sequences which basically almost ever anime has used at least once :) 

But, for someone coming into "The Legend of Heroes" series, this game is a great introduction, though technically in the teamline it is in the latter part of the universe. The visuals, yeah are not excellent 3D hyper resourced required models, but that doesnt take away from the beauty of the game, its sequences, action scenes, and the universe you start to explore. 

The music is beautiful, especially in the later part of the game where there are some truly majestic boss pieces that play in the background as you face some truly formiable foes. Also, during the quieter periods, the soft music that plays in the background could easy be used for a nice relaxing day in the real world. 

As i said, the charaters do have their torpes, but each is unique as you explore and learn more about them. The story unfolds slowly, which might annoy some people who want every question answered straight away. But the slow unfolding story allows you to take in what is occurring, and what might occur. 

The PC Port has been brillantly done and created, so much so you wouldnt even realize once you are ingame, that it was created for consoles. Additionally, the settings and options you can configure, will make it easy for many PC gamers to configure the game and tweak it to your hearts content. 

With this being the first game of four games for this story, there are still many unanswered questions, and the ending of this game has left me pumped for the next game to be released ported to PC in early 2018. 

While this game might not be flashy, its storyline, characters, music, universe, scenes and those little moments are something you rarely find packaged within a single game. If you are looking for a great JRPG, that has a expanding story and universe that will keep you exploring for hundreds of hours, I truly recommend you give "The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel" a go

38556944.review:
I've been playing JRPG's for a long time and love them, however a lot of them have a similar formula that is pretty predictable and can be stale at times, while Trails of Cold Steel doesn't reinvent the wheel it does a fantastic job at taking the core elements of what makes a good JRPG and builds on them. 

The combat is fun and flashy and can at times be challenging, sometimes there's a random difficulty spike but I never found myself being forced to grind all that much compared to some of the other JRPGs out there. The game is also pretty forgiving if you lose a battle. The characters and story are one of the best parts of the game. The characters really grew on me and I found myself wanting to do all the little side missions just to find out more about them. This game also has a few plot twist moments that will leave you speechless. The voice acting is pretty impressive as well. 

Some of the cons for the game though would be that the music didn't really blow me away. There are some tracks that stand out more than others but sometimes I found the music to just be lacking. The story also ends on a massive cliffhanger; there is a sequel on Ps3 that is coming to PC in 2018 but with no exact date yet it's hard to wait patiently. If that wasn't bad enough the game is part of a 4 part game series with parts 3 and 4 not being confirmed for the west yet. While steam only recorded about 40 hours the game took me about 65 hours to complete so like most JRPG's a decent amount of time needs to be invested.


Tl:DR: If you like JRPGs and haven't played this one yet you're doing yourself a disservice and should pick it up.

38425913.review:
Highly recommmend. Nihon Falcom strikes again with a killer, memorable, original, and thoroughly polished RPG!

First star goes to the original storyline. Rather, the deft handling of the storyline. One can spot a mile a way the many tropes that Falcom used to convey the story. As with most Falcom fans, the attention is given to the characters and how they react to the story. Nihon Falcom really takes to heart the writer's adage of "a simple story about complex characters". Once again, these NPCs are the most stand out characters in RPG history. The English voice acting is fun to hear. In my mind's eye (in addition to being predisposed), the actors sound exactly how I envision the characters to sound. I couldn't escape from hearing their specific voices in my mind when I was reading the silent dialogue.

One of the main complaints about Falcom's games is that they tend to have a slow beginning. I completely agree. The beginning ten hours are a labor of love when I play each game and I kinda doubt the game will go anywhere. By about the 12th hour, everything is set up so brilliantly and convincingly, that you must see things through as a play to the very end, even if that end is yet another 60 hours down the line. 

With that in mind, make sure you play this game during a month off of responsibilities; because it will eat up about 60 hours of your life. You'll be very content after that. Not an hour of those 60 wasted!

Next star goes to the killer soundtrack! The Falcom sound team outdoes itself with the best ambience, fight, boss, cinematic music ever! If you do not buy this game, at least purchase the soundtrack or listen to it online in order to get a taste of how epic the music is. Every city, character, sentiment is given a specific music piece, which means that when that music plays out of the blue, you know exactly what will happen. That's a great narrative technique. Nihon Falcom has had over umpteen games to perfect this winning formula.
I'd highly recommend playing the first Trails in the Sky games before playing the Cold Steel, because not only do some characters make a triumphant return, but also the combat system is the same from the Sky trilogy only refined and polished further. I admit it took about three Sky games to really perfect that combat system, and to pick up the small adjustments in this series for me as a veteran player went swimmingly. The next star goes to the game's polished mechanics. When I thought this series could not become more original or polished, out comes Cold Steel.
The graphics one could say is a bit dated even for when this game came out originally, back in 2013 I believe. But again, to play this game is not about the graphics; it's about immersing oneself into Falcom's world. The character models are a bit simple. But the simple designs lend themselves to doing nuanced actions. Characters blush, flirt, cry, dance, shutter, glare, and really convince you that they come alive with their actions. These NPCs again are much more alive than other games from this same era with more complicated graphics.
The final star goes to how the previous factors came together, which was a brilliant result. 

5/5 Stars. One of my favorites. Seriously, other corporations need to figure out what Nihon Falcom has been doing for the past coupla decades and crank out games like them. Each one is a serious hit in Japan and in the US. I hope our fanbase grows by the day! Send your love to X Seed to get CS II published!

38368465.review:
That has to rank as one of if not the dumbest “endings” I’ve ever seen.









 
 It was the Poe’s Law of Anime - I could no longer tell if things were supposed to be serious. 

I CHALLENGE YOU AND YOUR MAGICAL TALKING CAT TO A DUEL! GIANT ROBOTS AT ONE HUNDRED PACES!!! 
…

While I’d otherwise be willing to give the game a thumbs up, this just… Wow. The ending was such a resounding symphony of stupid I’m kind of reeling. I know that in JRPGs, a lot of tropes are to be expected. Oftentimes even appreciated. But, rather than having them highlighted throughout the game, worked in and established as part of the world, this just piled them on full force in the last couple scenes. Imagine if the Lion King ended in a pie fight - that’s how this game’s ending” feels.  

Not to mention the final fight was all new nonsense mechanics you’d never encountered before - any game that pulls that immediately loses immense points. Not that the game was perfect - there were way, WAY too many instances of the always infuriating, never excusable “oh, you thought you beat the badguy, but WAIT they were JUST HOLDING BACK!!!” where your hard fought victories amount to nothing. This includes a literal instance where the enemy in question goes “guess I don’t have to hold back!” It’s ridiculous. Victory blue balls. 

Including, once again, the “ending”. 

Ultimately, while I enjoyed playing this, the “end” was such a rushed, crazy, stupid cliffhanger of holes, logical lapses, and obnoxiousness I have to give it a thumbs down. This just squandered all its promise, and failed completely to deliver.

38318476.review:
本来想打完再写的，看了下进度，打完至少还要10小时，到时候怕不是咕咕咕了，还是现在写算了。由于没打完，剧情就不写了，随便写点其他的吧。
      目前的游戏信息：游戏时间49小时左右（挂卡6小时），全员平均54级，剧情位于第六章中期，导力孔全开，除了终极武器外应该算毕业了。

    先放两个重要的帖子：
    汉化及日文语音补丁：https://tieba.baidu.com/p/5328402482? （注：打日文语音补丁后可能有些对话就会无语音，因为英文语音数量比日文语音多）
    攻略（不喜欢的可跳过）：https://tieba.baidu.com/p/3579105481?

    本人是用XBOX手柄玩的，所以下面的键位以XBOX键位为准

    基本操作（左右摇杆就不说了）：
LB：选择link的人；RB：加速跑（战斗模式下是换人）；RT:快进对话，LT暂时没用过;
start键：弹出说明（任务说明，对话复述等）；X：在地图上快速传送（仅限在城内，迷宫内无法使用）/在触发link时是全体攻击; Y（配置武器，使用物品。配置道理回路。存档等）/触发link时是双人攻击；A:确定，B:取消
  

1. 本作是回合制RPG（废话），所以攻击顺序很重要，刷怪的时候尽量要抢先手攻击，因为先手攻击基本上可以让我方队员连续行动两回合，配合link系统或范围魔法基本可以秒三四个敌人。先手分三种，一种是直接从后方接近怪物，一种是从后方发动原野攻击将敌人击晕再进入战斗，一种是从正面直接将敌人击晕在进入战斗。第三种用得少，只记得用劳拉打出来一次，第二种用得最多，流程是先把怪吸引过来，然后按RB加速跑开，等怪不再面向你并后退的时候再靠近攻击，打出优势攻击状态。如果没打出优势攻击的话，至少要正面打，不能背向敌人，让敌人打出优势攻击，否则一群怪一上，轻则减员，重则团灭，实在遇到了直接丢烟雾弹逃跑。

2.关于导力系统：本作有直接决定魔法的回路（我只玩了空轨3部，没玩过零碧，不确定零碧有没有直接决定魔法的回路），不像空轨的回路只有属性，一定数量的属性自动获得魔法，也有核心回路（可升级，升级后不需要魔法回路也能用一系列的导力魔法），所以搭配回路还是有点玩法的。顺便说一些我认为比较有用的回路吧：
菜刀流：各种刃（玄武刃之类），各种牙（破迅之牙，破零之牙），练气（放S技必备），霸体。
魔法流：死神，熏风，银色荆棘，恶魔镰刀等一系列输出魔法以及熟悉的EP2，省EP2等。
奶妈：治愈（水属性恢复），复苏术（至于不能复活战斗不能的队友），丰饶，天使圣环，龙脉等。
其他；探知（知道地图中宝箱位置），幸运（增加怪物掉东西几率）等
顺便，如果回路名字中带有R，则说明该回路除了有相应魔法外还加一定属性。此外，本作基本不怎么需要自己合回路，靠宝箱和任务给的回路基本够用，最多自己和几个HP2和攻击2。


3.关于角色：本作的艾略特和艾玛定位基本上是奶妈（我认为艾略特当奶妈更强），其他人走魔法流或者菜刀基本都没问题，不过由于本作有link系统和核心回路的存在，当菜刀流要强得多，只需每个人带个强力的时/幻/空的魔法，其他的配属性回和各种刃吧。

4.关于link系统：简单来说就是可以在一个人普通攻击/战技攻击的同时，link的人（不一定是一个）有一定几率对同一目标进行攻击的系统，等价于共计两次。当然，link除了攻击外还有突然加血，突然防御等功能，详细功能可参见游戏内说明。

5.关于任务/委托：由于可能涉及剧情就不作剧透了。不过个人感觉任务重复度略高，每一章的流程干的事都差不多，可能空轨也是如此，只是没有发现而已。而且主角群作为帝国学生，干得怎么全是游击士的活…….

 6.关于迷宫地图：迷宫中的宝箱全开了吧，都是好东西，这次的宝箱很容易就能分辨里面是否有魔兽，开魔兽宝箱注意下就好（基本上就是大规模的当前地图的怪物，爆S技可破）。此外，尽量把地图中有些能打碎的箱子/罐子都打碎，会掉道具或者鱼饵一类的东西。到了中后期，迷宫中可能会有一些可破坏的路障，需要劳拉/马奇亚斯/米奇亚姆三个角色的原野攻击才能打碎，所以最好确保自己的队伍有这3人之一或更多，不然可能卡任务。

其他：
1，本作只有很少的任务会直接给米拉（游戏内货币），少部分给的是耀晶石块（可在在任意商店兑换为米拉，打怪也会掉），大部分直接给物品。所以游戏前中期很缺钱（一周目），所以省着点用，前期就买武器，不急于换防具。

2，记得把每次自由活动日的羁绊点数用掉，有特殊剧情（找特定角色npc对话触发，可参考攻略），也会加link值，提升link等级。

3，记得多存档，尤其是打boss前，有些boss的攻击会让我方角色获得不利的buff（混乱，即死，眩晕等），打之前可以参考攻略，带好相应的防护饰品。

我个人不喜欢本作3D化的人物，觉得大概空轨那种人物与背景设计符合我的期望，不过总体来说还是是满意的，毕竟也愉快的刷了快50小时。

38153130.review:
A great jrpg with a fantastic port, featuring additional quality of life options, pc enhancements, and tons of additional, high quality voice acting.

Quality of life includes:
Turbo mode - for speeding through animations you've seen before and wringing every last piece of dialogue out of npcs
Autosaves - comes in 1, 5, and 15 minute varieties
Button prompts for both Xbox and Dualshock controllers

PC enhancements include, but not limited to:
Graphical options including unlimited draw distance, (high quality) depth of field options, 60 fps and unlocked frame rate,
       "High" preset graphic options set runs great on older pcs.
KB/M control (I play exclusively with controllers, but the option is there for those who want it)

The game itself is fun to play, but recommended for those who enjoy long stretches of story segments interspersed with combat/exploration segments. The story has a nice, positive tone with the occasional moments of melodrama that really makes you root for the protagonists. Cast list is full of varied and quirky characters, and that includes the npcs as well. NPCs often have little side stories that makes the game world feel more alive than the average rpg. Talk to everyone (twice)!

Combat is fast paced and regular usage of special abilites and magic is expected. The paradigm is focused on taking immediate control of battles and keeping control - doing everything right tends to make combat feel a little too easy, but screw up and even random encounters can wipe you out. As the game goes on the lethality of random encounters is reduced (due to having more options in battle and equipment), but bosses will always happily take control of battle from you should you give them a chance. I played on Hard, those who are experienced with rpg combat may want to play NIghtmare.

A fine game and an excellent pc port.

38046209.review:
There are a whole lot of fans for this series, which seems to have a growing following. But whether or not you'll like this game depends wholly on what you're looking to do. If you want a hack and slash RPG that has fast action and a quick pace, this game is not for you. If, on the other hand, you greatly enjoy a game that is heavy on the story, you may have just died and gone to Valhalla. 

I've been a gamer forever, and have played hundreds of titles. I have never in my gaming history experienced a game that is so heavy on the storyline. You will be bombarded with cutscenes and dialog every literal step of the way. There is no skip option, so if you don't have time for all that, don't pick up this title. You've been warned. 

That said, you're less likely to enjoy this game if you're an older gamer. Let's face it, we've heard all the basic scenarios before, and most of the dialog, though beautifully done, will probably come across as mundane to most older RPG fans. That, and also the fact that we have jobs, families, and lives to get to. It's really less like a gaming expeirence and more like watching an interactive anime. Which is cool, but I think it's been done way over the top in this title. 

Aside from the storyline, the combat sequences are very good. There is a combo system, along with magic (functions like materia, ala FF7), leveling, etc. All the traditional things you would expect from an RPG are represented here. However, I have two gripes that are difficult to get my head around. 

First, the game is nowhere near an open world experience (at least not at the point I am in the game). It is entirely linear, so much so that, upon completing a quest, you advance days of the calendar year. Each day represents a certain timeframe in the gameworld, and only during those timeframes can certain things be done. If you miss out on talking to someone, getting a hidden quest, or purchasing an item, you're screwed. That means that unless you're playing with a guide, this game takes far too long -- you literally have to revisit every area and talk to everyone again each time the storyline advances. It's an interesting dynamic, but serves to slow down the action even further. To it's credit though, I will say that it offers an immersive experience having to talk to everyone and revisit things over again....though for most people you will just click the mouse a hundred times to get past the mountains of dialog. 

Second, the combat system is a lot of fun, but it is a bit slow. It is far more strategic than typical RPGs, but primarily because you can't power level to dominate your opponents. The experience you gain from battles diminishes each time you level -- and since this is not an open world environment, it's obvious the developers wanted you within a certain level range for each chapter of the story. Yes, you can sit there for hours to gain a few more levels, but its truthfully not worth it -- especially since the first battle you fight in the next chapter is going to automatically level your characters. The worst part of this system is that battles within chapters never really get any easier, either. You can pack on 5 levels by grinding for 3 hours, but you're probably only shaving a few seconds off each battle, which average out out to 1-2 minutes per. 

Pros:
Visually stunning, even though the graphics are outdated
Incredibly good voiceovers, and a whole lot of them
Fantastic cutscenes 
Story and Dialog are all extremely well done. They were paying attention to the details for this game
Great combat dynamics with all the essentials
Very immersive, with great character development

Cons:
Very slow paced (expect to dedicate a lot of time to progressing this game)
Linear 
Combat gets repetitive
Money -- While you don't have to grind for levels, you do have to grind for money, and currency for essential upgrades
Not able to skip the numerous and lengthy cutscenes
Too much pointless dialog

OVerall:
Good game if you have the time to play it, love storyline and character development above combat, and want an immersive experience

TLDR: This game is an amazing JRPG, worth full price. If you get it on sale, that's just a bonus.

I'm someone who played Trails in the Sky (a sort of unrelated prequel trilogy in the same world) and thought it was trash. Trails in the Sky actually got  one of the few negative reviews I've ever written. I thought it had potentially, but was let down in way too many ways, so I thought I'd give this game a go.

While Trials of Cold Steel doesn't fix every Issue trails in the sky had, it does enough in every area to turn it from a bad game into an increible one.

Random battle combat: Trails in the sky had unrewarding combat that you had to slog through. Every single fight whittled you down enough to cost the mana or item for a heal. In return for fighting, you got a little money (shit all) and very little exp. If you are 2 levels above the enemies in the area, you get 1 exp. This was my biggest complaint with the game.

In Cold steel, you can get through a lot of fights wihtout taking damage (think persona). The rewards still aren't great, but they are improved. You get moderate (maybe a little to the low side) experience, and a decent amount of money. Most fights you don't really need to think about, but things can get out of hand if you screw up too badly, so it keeps it relatively interesting. You have a tonne of spells that can be used by any character, and abilties that are character specific, meaning who you choose to have in your party matters and will change how you fight. I would say the combat is better than average for a turn based rpg.

Boss Battle Combat: The bosses are usually very well designed. Each character has an ability called an 'S break' (Basically a limit break in final fantasy). It's charged by taking damage, dealing damage, or using some spells or abilities. Random enemies will almost always be one hit by these abilities. Bosses however, can usually take well above 4 of these abilities to kill, which means that you can't just enter a fight and murder the bosses by using each characters S break (parties have a maximum of 4 units with a further 2 on standby). The battles feel epic, and though you get into a routine after you have worked out what to do in each battle (for example have main character use normal attacks, one person heal, one person buff and another using attack abilities or something to this effect) you will often have to change this up. Maybe a character gets KO'd or you take a bit more damage or you get a status effect or the enemy is using a stronger aoe ability. Boss battles are engaging and have you of the edge of your seat. You can't switch off your brain or you will lose. You almost always feel like an underdog against a boss, but they are always possible to win.

Story: Exactly the same problem as Trails in the Sky: There is a fuckton of dialogue, but that doesnt amount to a fuckton of story. Everyone talks so GODDAM MUCH, and very very little of it matters. I get that the designers want to create a world, but for goddsake, learn to show and not tell. It's the weakest part of the game BY FAR. The actual story is decent, it is just surrounded by so much bullshit that I can't find myself caring. Spend 20 minutes talking to everyone about who gives a shit what, and that 20 mins can by summarised by "there are bad people. stop the bad people." Really, the story isn't that bad, but the STORYTELLING is really awful.

Game flow: I don't really know what to call this. What I mean is that the game's chapters follow the exact same formula. Do missions around the school > Investigate old school (battle enemies) > Do teachers exam battle > Go on a train for a field trip > Do missions at new place > Beat a boss > Do more Missions at same place > have a section that is related to the story in the new place, usually ending in a terrorist fight > go back to school > repeat. 

If this had happened once or twice it would be okay, but it happens every time. it just makes the formula for the story of the game so plain, which adds to why the story is the weakest part.

Music: Increible. Gets you hyped. Makes battles feel fun and engaging. You will find yourself humming it.

Character/Party Customisation: Very good. Every character has a role that is assigned by the devs: eg Luara is a high damage character, Fie is the fast one, Emma is the damage mage, etc. However, you can play any character however you want (to a degree). If you equip a character with the right spells, equipment, and base magic ability 'orbment', you can passably play any character how you want. You can afford to play a character sub optimally, because the spells that everyone can use cover for glaring weaknesses.

Characters: They are interesting and likeable. You can form bonds that give you bonuses like in Persona. You can form links in battle that do things like let your partner attack if you crit an enemy. They all feel unique and their skills match who they are. They 'show don't tell' much better with the characters than the rest of the story, and it pays off well.

'Side missions': There are a lot of optional side missions that are literally just go to point A, talk to someone, go to point B, talk, Point A, Point C, point A, mission complete. They suck. I used a guide to get through them. As I said earlier, the game has a dialogue fetish. It wants to build the world, but this is a piss poor way of doing it. Combat missions are better 100% of the time. Combat missions are more engaging 100% of the time.

Even worse, there are special 'hidden missions'. you get these by 'stumbling across the right person at the right time'. By that, I mean you follow a guide to find them, because it could literally be a little girl in the middle of a kitchen in an army base that you literally never need to go into. That mission was another 'go to point A then B then A then B then A'. If you don't do these hidden missions, even if they are a waste of time, you can't get an S rank for the chapter. If they werent in the game, the game would be better, because you get rewards based on your ranking for the chapter, so you want to do them.

Overall: I would say the combat carries this game, but it doesnt need to. There is more than enough good, and the combat just adds to it. I have said a lot of negatives here, but that's because other reviews will focus on the positives. The Combat is great. The world is great. The storytelling sucks ass, and the formula of the game is glaringly obvious. It's not a bad formula, but it would be better if it was shaken up more. This game is interesting, there are parts of the story that are awesome and keep you playing. I will be buying and playing the next game as soon as it comes out.

37941886.review:
I wrote a long review and then steam crashed. I'm not writing it again. I've played some Tales, Star Ocean, and Final Fantasy games, but this is my first Trails.

There's a lot of basic quality of life stuff missing that's pretty standard in RPGs (e.g. no gear comparison in item shop, no sort functions in inventory). Some mechanics and quartz work inconsistently (e.g Detect quartz not working on Aurochs Canyon Path 3).  Combat links just being constantly severed (not due to enemy advantage) and character disappearing with my quartz and items.. just annoying. Other RPGs simply handle all these better. They don't even bother explaining the rules to the Blade minigame correctly.

I enjoy the characters. I enjoy their personalities and interactions. I really enjoy the combat and quartz mechanics. 

I don't enjoy the incredibly gated and linear design and boring level layouts. I also don't enjoy missing a volume of Red Moon Rose...

Oh, and roughly 90% of the dialogue in this game is just hot garbage filler that simply takes up time and space. 

The game has all the chackmarks of a JRPG that I wanted. Fishing, weapon upgrades, grinding, combat depth, social links, combat links, recipes, bestiary, etc. It just doesn't really pull off anything particularly well. Oh, times to trash that subpar bestiary. Why can't they list the enemy attacks?

Some people (a lot of people) don't care about most of what I listed. They probably enjoyed this game. All I know is that this is the first JRPG I've disliked enough to right a review about.

This game, and Trails series in general; is a slow burn. It took it's time for the story to move and the characters to develop in satisfying way. Thankfully this port Turbo Button eases up the pain and made the combat a lot more faster. You don't need to grind in this game, you just need to capitalize on enemy weakness and behaviour, or just stack impede quartz to win forever.

The main draw of this series is Falcom amazing works at worldbuilding and making the world feel lived in. The huge chunk of enjoyment of this game came from how every single people in this world reacts to the story development and having their own story arc. If that is what you want from your RPG, this is the best series for that.

37753810.review:
The Golden Age of J-RPGs has ended. No longer can we expect to see a plethora of J-RPGs coming every year. This time has come and past, and some people do not hesitate to state that J-RPG, as a genre, is dead. Do I agree? Not quite. While it is true that the genre is less represented than before, some developers are hell-bent to keep making this type of game, and they can be divided in two categories. Those that keep trying to make the genre evolve, like Square-Enix, and those that focus on the core aspects, like all the J-RPGs made with RPG-maker that strive to recreate that nostalgic feeling of the SNES era.

If I were to put Falcom in one of these two categories, it would definitely be in the second one, with the interesting particularity that it's a relatively big studio, which means they can afford to be more ambitious, graphically speaking, than little indie devs. This means that what they do, is keep making J-RPGs with a PS1/PS2/Dreamcast vibe. Unlike Square, they don't focus on beautiful graphics and real-time action, no, they put their focus on what they've done well for the past decade : writing, music, and turn-based combat design.

Why all these info, why not speak about the game directly? Well, because if you're a fan of good J-RPGs of the PS1/PS2/Dreamcast era, I'm sure you already frantically installed this game to see what all these good reviews are all about. And if you're not in that category, then I hope it will allow you to know what to expect, more than detailing the strengths and weaknesses of Trails of Cold Steel.

Some people like to point out how everything in Cold Steel feels generic and already seen. I won't argue, but I want to point out that while Falcom does heavily use tropes and clichés, such as child-characters, a school-setting in Cold Steel 1, and things like that...they use them in the right way : not as the "be all end all" of an idea, but as the starting point for writing it and giving it an interesting swing. This is what makes the characters lovable, the world believable, and the story interesting.

Finally, I want to put some perspective about this game. It's part of The Legend of Heroes series, comprised of J-RPGs that are set in the same universe, but are separated in arcs of 2 to 4 games. Each arc takes places in a different country of the main continent, and they are only separated by a couple years, or take place at the same time. As of now, there are three arcs : the Trails in the Sky arc, the Ao/Zero arc, and the Trails of Cold Steel are. The Sky arc has two games plus one side-story and is available on Steam, the Ao/Zero is not officially translated unfortunately (yet!), and Trails of Cold Steel will have four games, this one, the second should come out on Steam early 2018, the third one is out in Japan (count roughly 1-3 years for the translation), and the fourth one is in development. Falcom has also stated that they plan to do a fourth arc in the future.

This means that The Legend of Heroes, for how generic its name feels, is in fact the sole J-RPG series with so many games set in the same universe and that take place roughly at the same time. And Falcom does intend to keep making these games. Of course, if all the games are bad, or of diverse quality, it would not be that interesting, but Cold Steel 1 is considered one of the weakest entry in the series, a sentiment I kinda share, and it's still a damn awesome game.

For a J-RPG fan, this is something to follow : a whole ongoing series with an excellent average quality, that even at its lowest is still superior than the majority of the genre. So, is the J-RPG genre dead? Actually no, it may not be as flamboyant as before, but it's still very alive and kicking. Because, why fix what isn't broken?

37671621.review:
I play a lot of RPGS, and a fair few of them are JRPGS. I can say with confidence that is one of the best ones I have ever played. There are quite a few things that they did correctly in this game, and there are just a few things that I would like to see changed.
 
Pros:

Combat 
- Classic turn based but they keep the abilities and the mechanics interesting enough that it does not get stale.

Characters 
- Most of the characters have been fun and interesting to listen to. I find myself waiting for the next playthrough 
so i can engage in different bonding events to learn about different characters. 

Story 
- I am only on Chapter 3 but thus far the story and world are interesting, lots of mystery surrounding every character so far and still lots more to discover in the world.

Turbo
- I never played original but apparently this was not in it. Turbo makes traversing the maps so much faster, great idea

Difficulty
- Rare to see a genuine difficulty setting in many JRPG games from a couple years ago but it exists here. It is very difficult to out level your opponents and combat can always surprise you with a butt kicking. Although I have never recieved a Game Over on normal difficulty I have come close and that is a great feeling.

Play Time
- 80 hours of good story for $30, yes please.I say 80 hours because that what I should average in a playthrough since I am purposely opening all chests and talking to all npcs.

Cons:

Its a small thing but I would like to the costumes unlock after they are used in game rather than on new game+ The entire first playthrough you are stuck in the uniforms which the main character simply does not look that great in. 

The repetitive nature of the field studies is starting to show. As I said I am only on chapter 3 but having repeated essentially the same exact process 3 times in a row just in different places is a bit strange. I have a feeling this is not going to be this way for long.  

If you want to complete 100% for any of the completionists out there, get ready to look up a guide. I noticed I missed a few books already which apparently are traded for super powerful weapons. Not necesaarily a con for me but some people will think so. 

Conclusion
Amazing game that any JRPG fan would be insane not to pick up. All i can think about is when the sequals will be releasing because of how much fun I am having in this game right now.

37624977.review:
I've never concidered myself a fan of RPG's in general. I'd played Fallout and Skyrim and a few of its contemporaries, but no RPG seemed to scratch my itch. Then, I watched a video by Mother's Basement  ( [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TaN2G-AEd9Q] linked here [/url] ) in which he described his love for Japanese developer Nihon Falcom and their incredible ability do build incredible worlds. 

I decided to pick up Trails of Cold Steel and Trails in the Sky not long afterward. I absolutely fell in love with this game from its Cold Opening (Pun intended) to its thrilling conclusion and every single moment in between. If you are like me and didn't play Trails in the Sky beforehand, the combat doesn't seem too complicated. If you have, you'll be rewarded with not only a similar combat system, but an improved one that has ties directly in with the lore of the Zemurian continent.

The characters, both playable and non-playable are fantastically written, the music is spectacular, and the voice acting is amazing. In short, this game is a must play. I've nominated it for the "No Apologies" Award for this year's Steam Awards. That's just how much I love this game.

37285269.review:
The Trails series are absolutely breath taking in terms of both gameplay and story.

Battle: The combat is a fairly customizeable turn based combat system. You equip different Jewels to different party members in order to obtain different spells. Each character also has their own individual skills that can be used aside from spells along with skills that are sort of like limit breaks from the FF series.

Story: The story starts off slow and becomes better and better leading up to a major cliff hanger at the end of the game. You start off as a student who is learning at a military academy who has to overcome many hurdles with his new classmates from different social statuses and forge bonds with them along the way. Also there are quite a few romance options for the main character as well. Although this blooms into fruitation in the 2nd game (your save data will carry over.)

I will update more as I have more time. Overall I rate this game around a 9/10 for a JRPG

37124969.review:
With a translation reflecting close attention to detail, and a pretty good voice-acting cast, Trails of Cold Steel brings the Trails series forward from XSEED's translation of the Famicom games. Trails of Cold Steel takes place on another part of the continent introduced in the Trails in the Sky trilogy that predates this series - JRPG fans who have not indulged in these games first might find themselves missing a few references/easter eggs in the Cold Steel series, but the game does more than enough to create its own separate environment that can be just as engrossing.

The best way to describe this game is a combination of the Trails in the Sky combat system with the day-to-day student lifestyle of games like the Persona series - fans of both should definitely give Trails of Cold Steel a fair shot.

36873047.review:
I've already played this game on the PS Vita (and loved it enough to Platinum it), and the PC port of this game fixes all of the technical problems that I had with the game.

ToCS is a great JRPG in a time when I'm finding my patience stretched thin by other JRPGs like World of Final Fantasy or the latest Pokemon generation. The story is quite slow-paced, but my opinion is that this works to the benefit of the game; the worldbuilding and unexpected depth of interaction with the numerous NPCs sets the stage properly for its sequels, but also tells a story of learning to work with others, even if at first glance, you find nothing in common or nothing likable. Despite its slow pacing, I don't think that ToCS wastes my time unnecessarily. You can choose how much you want to play, since the majority of quests are optional, and story-related mandatory quests interesting.

The core gameplay involves moving around a world filled with NPCs that each have their own stories to tell, in the midst of a growing national crisis. Combat is turn-based, but it is my favourite turn-based combat system to date, staying simple to understand at a basic level, but providing a great deal of tactical depth and satisfaction when fighting the wide range of boss fights.

As for the quality of the PC port, XSEED did a wonderful job of improving upon the original in terms of performance (basically no FPS stutters like in the original PS Vita version), and adding additional voiced lines for the protagonist, Rean, who had several scenes without voice-over when others did. The new Fast-Forward feature is also a welcome edition, especially since I was replaying the game, which saved me a lot of time in the story cutscenes and combat animations that I didn't need to see again.

As a final note, there is a method of replacing the voice-over audio with the original Japanese audio, if you have a preference for it.

This game the moment i started playing i was hooked. The game started off like it does with most games a bit slow, but once you played the first 5 hours of the game the story really kicked off. The way the game did it story was well structured it followed a pattern. You would go to classes, do tasks around school, have a test, then go on a school trip. Each school trip was its own unique and quite detailed map and you explored different sections of the world of trails of cold steel. Quests and tasks were all unique in there own way you never really found you were doing the same thing twice, you could be fighting monsters, delivering books, or looking for loot and still be having fun. All the characters have interesting back storys and there own relationships with eachother that can create a sense of intigue and humour at the same time.

It is the closest you can get to a persona like game on steam and and am looking forward to them porting the the rest of the trilogy as ive heard that your save file transfers between games for your social links with characters.

36821209.review:
9 цун-цун из 10. 
Плюсы игры: 
- Очень хорошо проработанный сюжет, который растягивается аж на три игры. Здесь мы пожалуй проходим только пролог всей сюжетной саги.
- Хорошо сбалансированная система боев с ИИ и возможность спокойно поменять любой Кварц (а-ля магический камень) на тот, что вам будет удобен в той или иной ситуации.
- Приятное музыкальное сопровождение, что мало когда надоедает и порой в битвах с боссами их не хочется проходить, а просто слушать это исполнение.
- Более менее приятная глазу графика (этот параметр для тех "специальных" людей, которые впервые суются в аниме-индустрию игр), хотя есть все же некоторые косые моменты с ней. 
Минусы: 
- Чисто для меня этим единственным минусом игры яявляется зашкварный стиль атаки по одному удару, что у тебя в открытом поле, что в бое и у тебя и у противников, что есть немного печаль, хоть во второй части саги в открытом поле, добавили допольнительные вариации атаки, но всё так же игра страдает этим минимальным, но вполне себе надоедливым минусом, что и заставляет меня ставить игре не полноценную десятку.

P.S: Чисто мое мнение и я не заставляю вас придерживаться точно такого же мнения как и я. Спасибо за то, что уделили время моему маленькому обзору и удачного прохождения, если вы купили эту великолепную игру.

P.S.S: Если вы хотите пройти игру на 100% то вам придется изрядно попотеть. Займет все у вас примерно на 150+ часов, если вы не будете сильно торопится и делать, как положенно в этой игре. 

P.S.S.S: Ну и если вы любитель хардкора для вас игра преподносит такую очаровательную вещь, как режим Ужаса (Nightmare), которая сбалансирована для NG+.

36780187.review:
The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel I picked this game (and some other ones) up on a whim just to satisfy a JRPG craving I was having and was really surprised by game itself. However, before I go on with giving a decent recommendation let me first preface and say most of the negative things you hear about this game are true. The game really develops at a slow pace, this is undeniable however if you consider this is the first in a four game series it is understandable. The voice acting is generally terrible, and there is no option to my knowledge to switch to Japanese language with English subtitles. Lastly the game doesn’t do anything incredibly unique in terms of mechanics making it rather unsurprising in terms of game play. 

That out of the way I was never once bothered by the lack of originality of game play mechanics, what is offered is what I expected and I didn’t feel that it detracted from the overall game. The story is unique, the characters are compelling, and the world feels sufficiently fleshed out to where I never felt like a dissonant element was introduced that broke my experience. In fact I was so absorbed in the world the developers created I played the game three more times just to ensure I got to see everything that is offered. The DLC’s offered are completely optional and are primarily just cosmetics minus some low priced game play boosts such as money, crafting material and some accessories. Most of which can be achieved through normal game play or multiple playthroughs. 

Anyway, I highly recommend Trails of Cold Steel to anyone that wants to play a solid JRPG and can handle bad voice acting.

36580267.review:
Cold Steel is something a player, a reader, an adventurer of their dreams needs to see and experience. 

It can serve as a jRPG, action-packed and very elaborated on its mechanics and terminology, or as a visual novel about life itself: plethora of insignificant and, therefore, precious stories are scattered around the Erebonian Empire and are dwelling in an everymen’s pockets and hats.

Such complexity is possible because everything — multiple chapters, focused attention on certain backgrounds and town aesthetics of all kinds — everything happens one at a time, and authors apply tireless efforts so you would never be overwhelmed. You can always pinpoint your position in the grand story, thanks to the in-game calendar, and with peace of mind place a ribbon amidst pages. Sure, Cold Steel is a charming book, where beneath an avant-propos emotions await their owner. 

Emotions that flourish each time an ambient resonates with a book. Theme of Nord Highlands awakes every bit of your freedom, melodies of Legram will make sure its landscapes are your most treasured ones and notes from the Abyss have an arcane taste of magic. The music will help you to remember forever every chapter, especially the final one, from beginning to end and to brace yourself in every battle. 

In the latter case, every element of the battle gameplay is one of the bestest jRPG can deliver: encounters lead to various types of satisfying level-ups, Class VII’s teamwork results in intimate chitchat, UI/sound design aims at kindling a brave’s spark. 

After all, Trails series is about the bravest, who are meant to make a family hearthside the warmest place in the world — again and despite all the calamities.

36576195.review:
So, nachdem ich jetzt um die 30 Stunden habe (Edit: Ich habe das Ende jetzt nach 49 Stunden erreicht und kann New Game Plus starten), muss ich sagen, dass sich jeder Cent gelohnt hat. Die Story ist noch weit entfernt davon, beendet zu sein, aber Junge, es war ein angenehmer Ritt. Sicher, vieles war vorhersehbar, aber im Großen und Ganzen war alles mit viel Liebe zum Detail erzeugt. Die Grafik mag nicht die beste sein, denn hey, es ist original ja ein PS Vita-Game, aber es ist trotzdem verdammt gut. Viele Cutscenes, viele abwechslungsreiche Gebiete, die zwar an sich klein ausfallen, dafür aber anständig designt wurden. Selbst riesige Rückwege spart man sich oftmals, weil man kurzerhand an die Hand genommen wird - das sorgt für ein umso stimmigeres Design, bei dem genau eines stets dominiert: Die Story. Und auch wenn sie am Ende durchaus fantastischere Züge annimmt, hat sie mir dennoch sehr gut gefallen.
Das Kampfdesign ist gut und macht auf jeden Fall laune, kann manchmal vielleicht etwas fitzelig und verwirrend ausfallen, aber das ist vermutlich dann eher meine persönliche Ansicht. Die Vertonung ist echt gut und man hat bei diesem Port auch das Gefühl, dass man die Sache anständig machen wollte.

Blöd nur: es wird auf einem Cliffhanger enden, der erst mit dem zweiten und dritten Titel dieser Reihe erzählt wird. Tatsächlich - und hier muss man aufpassen - wenn man alles in seiner Gänze verstehen will, müsste man alle 8(!) Teile der Saga (nämlich auch Legends of Sky und zwei noch nicht portierte Titel) spielen. Ich bin auf jeden Fall froh, diesen Titel gekauft zu haben und bei 40 Euro kann ich ruhigen gewisses sagen, dass es sich gelohnt hat.

Trails of Cold Steel es la undécima entrega de la saga The Legend of Heroes, por lo que si es el primer juego de la franquicia que jugáis, seguramente se os pasen un montón de referencias. Es preferible jugar antes la saga en orden cronológico.

Dicho esto, es un juego de 10: su banda sonora, ambientación historia y, sobretodo, personajes. Porque los juegos de esta saga se caracterizan por presentar a unos personajes muy humanos y creíbles, que van evolucionando a través del juego y a través de los juegos que componen la saga. Es completamente imposible que no os gusten la Clase VII y sus aventuras y penalidades que sufren durante todo el año escolar que comprende este juego.

Es por tanto una compra obligatoria para cualquier persona que le gusten los JRPG.

36280493.review: This is my first venture into JRPGs outside of the Final Fantasy series.  All in all, it was a great experience.  However, be warned that what folks say about this being a "slow burn" is true.  The "77.8 hours played" is a single playthrough on normal where I covered all of the main quests, as well as all of the side quests that were right in front of me, and perhaps a few "secret" quests.  There were probably more than a few "secret" quests that I didn't see.  Compared to the Final Fantasy series, I found this game to be equally challenging, but much more forgiving.  Level grinding was barely necessary and used very rarely compared to other games in this genre.  If you got the time, go for it, but ready for the long haul for this game compared to other ones in the genre.

Интересная улучшенная боевая система, многим кто играл в предыдущие игры серии она будет знакомой и родной с той лишь разницей, что у нас теперь модельки персонажей имеют трёхмерную модель. Гибкая система прокачки персонажей которая тоже большинству поклоникам серии будет знакомой. По мимо стандартных обвесов типа одежды и оружия на параметры персонажа влияет ещё и ваш "Орбмент", кристалы установленные в него влияют на персонажа давая ему магию определённой стихии или же поднимая его статы.. Из минусов стоит отметить, что игра на буржуйском языке, больше минусов не замечено. К графике думаю не стоит предираться она тут очень даже симпатичная, это по факту стандарт для большенства игр японского геймдева.

It does what the series does so well in making a world full of character and the NPC's feel like characters with substantial growth by endgame!  While I do think the characters are stronger in the Liberl arc, the characters in Cold Steel are still an extremely loveable cast!  And with the way this game ends...you'll definitely wanna pick up its upcoming sequel to finish this story off (well at least until we get Cold Steel 3 that is ;) ;) ;) )

And while I havent played the game entirely through on my PC (Just long enough to make sure it runs on my very basic non-gaming pc... and it does... very well ;) ), the improvements over the PS3 version are extremely noticeable, so kudos to them :)

36228270.review:
So, I put in about over 140 hours into this game, and also did a second playthrough. As a guy who played the original trilogy (this includes the 3rd and final installment which happened to have been a dungeon crawler more than a JRPG), I think I can give a pretty well rounded review of the game mechanics as compared to the previous games, the story, the characters and etc.

1) So, let's talk about the game mechanics. It follows the same basic premise of the battle system found in Trails of the Sky, except it's a bit more robust. They've added linked attacks which weren't present in the original trilogy, as well as more robust magic system (which is nice). So, I definitely enjoyed the upgrade battle system a lot.

What really bored me was the school setting, because you're pretty much boxed into the main town Trista. You're also forced to interact with the same characters, same NPCs and same environments over and over and over - and it can get rather dull and redundant at times. I also didn't like the quizzes sprinkled throughout the game. I don't like to be quizzed about a game's lore. That annoys me.

2) Now, let's talk about the graphics and environments. Well... The graphics are a bit better than the TotS trilogy, but of course, it's a port from a PSP game (I hear it's also on the PS3), so the graphics aren't exactly going to wow you. They did add a nice distance blur effect, which adds dimension to the environments, but that's about it. Many of the characters (or all of them) have very low poly counts, so you'll notice they look very blocky - especially up close. 

Unlike the previous games (I really should just say chapter one and chapter two of TotS), there's not a lot of environment to explore. You're first introduced to a town called Trista, but after you've explored everything about that town, you're kinda forced to get familiar with that town all the way up to the very end. Of course you visit other towns, but only small selected areas of those towns, and even then, when going to towns like Heimdallr, there are districts you can go to, but some districts are really very very linear, and you can only travel so far. It's not like the previous games where you could walk from one town to the other. When you go to a town, you're forced to finish off a list of quests before you can go off to the next one. Someone could argue that it was kinda the same way with chapter one and two of TotS, but at least I could walk from one town to the next without having to watch a cut scene each and every single time I traveled to a town.

3) How about the story and character development? Well, many of us (I'm sure) enjoy watching anime, and I'm no exception. This game follows behind the typical school setting of most anime out there. So, in regard to the setting in which the game takes place, it's very cliched. The story, of course, follows behind a kid named Rean Schwarzer who goes to a prestigious military academy. From there, he goes through field studies and gets thrust into various circumstances dealing with terrorists, rebellions and eventually a [spoiler]civil war[/spoiler]. (I'm trying not to spoil anything). 

People say the story is great, but I think it's pretty meh - at least up until the very last chapter. Then the game turns on its head and becomes one of the best moments I've played through. I think that may have a lot to do with the pacing. The story goes very very slow. In this game, it really just feels like they're preparing you for the meat and potatoes in ToCS II & III. So, in other words, it feels like a prequel of sorts until you play the _actual_ game and jump into the main crux of the story.

The game does make many references to the previous trilogy. It'll also bring up names and titles of characters from the previous game, and if you haven't played those games, you will be completely lost. I.E. The Enforcers or who Cassius Bright is. I have to admit, after playing through the previous trilogy, seeing "Olivert" playing his role as a prince did seem rather awkward (play the previous games to understand why).

The characters themselves are actually interesting, and each one has their own personality quirks. The dialog between them is quite fluid, but there are times when they discuss things unrelated to the main story that becomes rather boring. Often times I wondered what some of the dialog had to do with even developing their characters, but I digress.

4) So, here is my final verdict. It's a real good game and worth the purchase. Not a perfect game, mind you, but it's a solid JRPG and I can't wait until the sequel is available on Steam.

This game is great. Like look at the hours I put on it. I got a total of almost 400 hours of it from off and on gameplay. its been that kind of fun. if you dont like stories do not bother. i thought the story was fun and exploring characters and some extra play bonus was great too. 

I got so wrapped in the story that I actually just started watching gameplay vids for Trails of Cold Steel 2 til I finished watching it. And yes Trails of Cold Steel 2 seem like a great edition. 

With part 1 Trails of Cold Steel ; It deserves the praise.  The only thing perhaps thats annoying with all RPGs is that it is usually self centered around 1 character and you cannot really change out the Main character thorughout the story except through a few spoiler scenarios where that happens and thats very limited when that does happen. A few minigames here and there and somewhat pretty nice storyline to tie up all the predecessors of the series of Trails [which was done well with the story development]. 

When you start acquiring more of your squad; you can eventually have the option of who you would like and have the choice to have the lead in the back without having to play as the lead character [Which in some case kind of resolves that issue]. 

Fell in love with my ability of choice and being able to gravitate to other  optional scenarios in the game that built even NPCs with some personality. 

TL:DR -  consistently stays intact to its predecessors with unveiling the storyline and hints that other gameplay will be added in the next series.

36132224.review:
想了很久该如何写这则测评，因为我想给自己深爱的这一游戏系列以一个较为完好的反馈。
首先，我要诚挚地感谢FALCOM为我带来的感动与欢乐，无论是空轨中小约含泪离开时的悲恸，小艾一次又一次的苦苦追寻，两人再次相见时的拥抱，方舟崩坏前的深情一吻，凯文在面对心魔时爆发出的守护意志的圣痕，还是零轨支援科IBC门前为保护身后一切的七连战死守，又或是碧轨中纵然现实巨变仍坚持跨越壁障的决心，一切都是那么精彩那么引人入胜，非常感谢各位社员的努力。
当知道闪轨登录steam后便第一时间入了手，整个闪轨一是在用主角在学院中成长的的缓慢叙事方式来为我们呈现帝国甚至西塞姆里亚的动荡局势，节奏虽慢但不失细节处的精细。期待帝国片的后续。我在此呼吁大家耐心游戏，拒绝游戏快餐化，发掘游戏里隐藏的人性面。
最后，我希望银色的意志能架着金色的羽翼去探寻生命的道路，祝FALCOM事业蒸蒸日上。此生无悔入轨迹，希望喜爱轨迹的好朋友们人人都可以找到属于自己的路。（ps.b站已经可以预约晓之轨迹了，希望有空闲的朋友可以为预约人数捧场）。鄙人steam新人，如此则测评有冒犯之处还请多包涵。

36064562.review:
После прохождения Trails in the sky FC и SC, я ожидал от этой игры чего то грандзиоздного. Обычно в таких случаях "ожидающих" ждет разочарование, но только не в случае с Trails. Половину моих ожиданий игра оправдала полностью и половину превзошла. Каждые 5 минут из проведенных в игре 100ч я орал нечто вроде "ааааа ах****еноо!" или "да с*****ка!". Особенно это было ярко выраженно при первом запуске, когда я приготовившись после TiS увидеть на экране знакомые забавные изометрические картинки в стиле поздних 90х внезапно получил в глаз полноценным 3д и озвученными диалогами. Конечно это все еще не крузисо-ведьмако-ларокрофты, но тем не менее в техническом плане скачок на 10 лет вперед. Сюжет же вообще отдельная тема, впервые за многие годы ("со времен прочтения "10 негритят" Кристи) я не смог вычислить одного из главных антогонистов сюжета. Пусть лишь одного из десятка имеющихся, но для меня это был тот еще шок. Серьезно, загодя было ясно, что "Васенька скажет что-нибудь новогоднее", что "дырка замузыкает" [spoiler] та что у гг в груди [/spoiler] , что "Класс 7" это [spoiler] попытка Оливера создать свою Bracer Guild с блейдом и кошками [/spoiler] , что [spoiler] певичка не просто так [/spoiler] , что [spoiler] горничная еще скажет свое слово [/spoiler], что сонная девочка [spoiler] наемник [/spoiler] , что [spoiler] местное недодворянство устроит переворот  [/spoiler] , что [spoiler] дадут ОБЧРа погонять [/spoiler] , что Эмма [spoiler] может в особо сильное колдунство [/spoiler] и было ясно куда делось железо. 
Но вот ход с [spoiler] Кроу [/spoiler] был великолепен, с одной стороны подозреваый персонаж абсолютно очевиден, а с другой ты даже не пытаешься анализировать моменты, которые явно указывают на это. Быть может это от того, что с каждой стены гроздьями свисают "Чеховские ружья" и отовсюду торчат длинные уши [spoiler] Уробороса [/spoiler] , но отличного сюжетного хода это не отменяет. Ну а по пунктам:
Графика - прыжок во времени на 10 лет вперед относительно прошлой игры серии.
Сюжет - как и в прошлый раз славный гибрид из детектива, драмы, эпоса и комедии.
Звук - озвучка диалогов, о которой в прошлой части мечтать даже не приходилось и музыка, которую можно слушать часами(особенно боевая ближе к концу игры).
Персонажи - как и раньше уникальные, живые и заставляющие сопереживать. Есть конечно Анжелика блевотворная-на*-не нужная-которую-неплохо-бы-пустить-в-расход, но видимо без наличия в игре подобной мерзости ее бы запретили продавать в ЕС и штатах. Слава яйцам, что эта мерзость в сюжете редко появляется.
Геймплей - "easy to learn but hard to master", порадовала система комбо атак, а вот разделение кристалов на обычные, статовые и кастовые неплохо так усложнило бои.
Зашкаливающее количество миниигр.
О грустном:
Концовка один толстый, оооочень толстый, сочащийся жиром клиффхэнгер, в разы толще чем было в TiS FC. И это не было бы печально,  а даже наоборот захватывающе, если бы в продаже уже был бы порт второй части, а так ждать его еще минимум до декабря.
Итого 10000000 из 10.
А теперь обращение к разработчикам: Анонсируйте, черт вас дери, хотя бы дату релиза второй части на pc, я даже предзаказ готов сделать хоть за 10 кратную цену, не заставляйте меня устраивать нудные бубнотанцы с глючным эмулятором...

35937878.review:
I played Tales of Symphonia with a friend back in the day, and thought JRPGs were never gonna be like the old days ever again.  Well, I was wrong.  Color me impressed with the outstanding effort given to localization, optimization, and straight up porting efforts by the team assigned to port this.  I read their blog and was surprised by how much thought they put into porting this over to the PC, with the addition thought of properly localizing this huge piece of work.

Aside from that, I love the gameplay.  I never thought I'd sink a significant amount of time into a JRPG ever again, but here we are.  It's fairly linear (don't expect to wander around too much) in terms of map design and direction, so don't expect to get lost (which is a good thing).  Gameplay is deep, and there's so many mechanics in play that you could get stomped in a boss fight if you never take advantage of any of them, while sweeping the floor in as little as 5 turns if you do take full use of them.

Other thoughts—The story is great.  It starts off reaaally slow, then suddenly gets me stoked for every chapter as soon as the pace picks up.  And another fun thing: You end up caring about the NPCs.  Never in a game have I chatted up every NPC to see what's going on after every story event.  They all have names, and even crazier, they have character bios!

Anyway, be prepared to sink tons of hour into this puppy.  It's massive, and the included turbo mode (many thanks for implementing that!) helps so much.

35756888.review:
A genuinely great game. I love Turn-based JRPGs so this game was a natural pick-up for me. I hadn't heard of the series before nor had I played any prior installments and yet I had no trouble learning about (and getting immersed in) the world this game is set in. Sure the plot has some cliches here and there (Hero boy has some special unique power, he happens to be in the right place at the right time throughout the story and other such tropes) but they're completely offset, in my opinion, by the way the game pushes into the player into the situations and if that's not enough for you then the plot twists will definitely re-engage your interest in the plot. The world is an enjoyable one and if you're a nerd for lore like I am then you'll find you've spent far too much time in this game reading books about the history of the world or talking to sub-characters to squueze out any information you can.

The Characters for the most part are all very likeable and have their reasons for acting the way they do, some secretive about their past/families, others outright hostile to certain individuals through beliefs they hold which have never really been challenged by those around them, only enforced. The only character I didn't like from the main cast was Emma, she felt very bland backstory-wise through most of the game and even when other characters started to open up or give individuals a chance she only really dropped hints about herself (until the end where she half-reveals her past) and I can only assume that she will give us the full story in the sequel.

The battle system, whilst not revolutionary, was overall enjoyable. Being able to custom tailor your characters via quartz' was certainly a system that allowed you to feel like the characters were yours and not preset into roles (to an extent) like so many other JRPGs. Whether it be switching Master Quartz' to change a characters playstyle somewhat drastically or switching up the regular Quartz' to fine tune your characters and their ablilties/stats made each decision feel like it had an impact upon your characters, a minor one at first but as the quartz' got more powerful the choices of what to equip became harder. The characters unique abilities all felt good to use in battle and all served certain purposes whether it be knocking back enemies so that you could survive another turn, an AoE to quickly clear out weak/low hp enemies or to heal your whole team. This made party composition quite important and made you have to choose carefully about who you brought into battle (when you're given the opportunity to choose who you can have).

Finally, the waifus (or husbandos for those so inclined). As I mentioned prevoiusly the characters all (bar one) have interesting and enjoyable personalities and have multiple layers to them which makes improving your relationships with them all the more rewarding. At the end of the game you get to make a choice of who to spend the festival with. You can pick from pretty much any of the major characters and a few of the sub-characters (assuming you've achieved the pre-requisites) and you get a nice heart-to-heart scene from the characters (no love confessions, just good quality bonding time). Alisa is the obvious choice for this as she is the girl that the plot pushes towards you but there are so many options that you shouldn't need to go for her out of obligation (saving before the festival can allow you to experience a few of the heart-to-heart scenes if you want to try a few out). My personal favourite is Sara Valestine, the alcoholic teacher but I'l llet you decide your waifu (or husbando) for yourself.

I get that with this review I'm pretty much just preaching to the choir as most likely only fans of the game will see it, but, if you're thinking of buying this game and are looking through reviews beforehand then I strongly recommend buying and completing this game.

Subjectively I'd give this game a 9/10
Objectively it's more of a 7-8/10 
But in the end only you know what you like so I can only hope you enjoy.

35698088.review:
The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel (or 英雄伝説 閃の軌跡 Eiyuu Densetsu Sen no Kiseki in japan) is a role-playing video game developed by Nihon Falcom. As a part of The Legend of Heroes series, it was first released for the PS3 and PS Vita September 2013. English version is later released at the end of 2015. Followed by PC port in late 2017. The game sets in the same universe of that of famous Trails of the Sky series.

The quality of PC port is on the top form. With introduce many of PC exclusive features such as a built-in turbo mode, auto save etc. There's little to no bug or crash at all.

The game is set in the Erebonian Empire. Rean Schwarzer, the 17 years old who enrolls at Thors Military Academy and a main character of this game, find himself in the military-powered Erebonian Empire struggles with its internal conflict, the upper class and commoners attempting to rise to power both militarily and politically, their struggle for power steadily intensifies with each passing day. Rean, himself will soon learn all these experiences throughout the new class program invested by The Thors Military Academy called Class VII, where in this very class, rank means nothing but skill means everything. Rean's adventure along with Class VII's nine hand-picked students from various backgrounds and different class, begin through the political quagmire that threatens them and the very foundation of the Empire itself. 

Though not only they have to face the country problem, but as well as their own flaws. These students will find themselves having to come up with own resolve and moving forward together into big elegant yet unknown world, and surviving together out there.

In Trails of Cold Steel, the player controls a cast of characters, embarking on a number of quests to progress the story.  There are two different type of maps when navigating in the overworld of the game: field maps(dungeon) and town maps. In field maps, enemies roam around and a battle ensues if the player comes in contact with one. In town maps, the player can visit various shops to purchase items, replenish health at an inn and, for the major cities, take on and report quests to the client. In addition, the player can interact with numerous non-playable characters (NPCs) in the game. The unique aspect things in the legend of heroes series is that each NPC's dialogue changes as the game advances, allowing the player to follow along sidestories that accompany the NPCs throughout the game, making a world itself feel much more lively.

In addition to typical RPG standard gameplay like exploring town and dungeon. The game also brings in the school life element into Cold Steel. Which mean not only they'll be making a journey throughout the land, the students will also be attending in classroom, and have to study various subject much like school life, and hang out with other friends in campus as to learn more about them and strengthen the bond with them. School will be considered as the main base where characters will find themselves hanging around most of the time.

Combat in Cold Steel takes place on an small open battlefield turn-based, where your characters can move freely within their moving range assuming that it's their turn. During the character's turn, the player can move or make an attack. Each character also have three other methods available for attack/support: Arts, Crafts, and S-Crafts. Arts are kind of action involving magic spells that characters can use to attack opponents or support teammates but must take an additional turn to cast as well as using EP as a cost. Crafts are character individual abilities that are similar to Arts but can be used in the same turn; however, they utilize a special gauge called "Craft Points" (CP) for the cost to perform. S-Crafts are powered-up Crafts that can be performed once a character has over 100CP but completely depletes the CP gauge upon using it. Further extending S-Crafts are S-Breaks which allows characters to immediately perform an S-Craft regardless of when their turn order is.

The "Tactical Link System" also introduced in this game, which allow players to follow up with three different kinds of link attacks, dealing additional damage and providing various other benefits. Tactical Links becomes a more useful asset to the player as the story progress and characters level up their "Link Levels" or "Bond" with other characters. In addition to that, the game also introduces Orbment system, which allow player to customize "Master Quartz" and "Quartz" which has various effect mostly related to battle, such as allow player to use certain Arts or make your regular attack able to cause status debuff on enemy. Master Quartz and Quartz also gives addition status on character, making them generally more powerful.

The game offers your quite an alright challenge and reasonable balance. Player will be forced to use various tactic like buff and debuff in other to gain upper hand in combat. As well as utilizing the Tactical Link System. There's no need for grinding level since the gap on enemy level in each sector is by no mean big. EXP multiplier is depended on player's performance during a combat, you will always get the decent among of exp as long as you fight them with your best. 

In addition to main gameplay. The game include some of mini game activities such as fishing, cooking etc. They reward player with an useful items that can be used during on main story journey, make it easier to progress with lesser problem. 

The game's scenery is very beautiful and engaged with well composed music in a background. Story itself flows very nicely and addicting with worth of 70+ hours pure story telling excluding battling and grinding. Involving not only sci-fi but also super nature and magic. Balancing with political story and divine-legend alike. You will be seeing several moments of memorable, and make you want to find out about this massive world more. It's truly worth calling this game has taste of JRPG game from golden age. I recommend any RPG gamer to give this ones a try, and you will never regret spending time on playing this gem.

35632992.review:
为了信仰买的这游戏，当年闪1和闪2在PSV上起码通关了两三遍，真的是好游戏！！！
经常看评论有人说闪轨垃圾，根本没有空轨的剧情好。我想对那些人说能不能深深的仔细的体会闪轨的美。
很多人之所以喜欢空轨，是因为空轨非常唯美得叙述了约修亚和艾丝蒂尔的凄凉而又温暖甜蜜的爱情故事.
也有人非常喜欢零轨和碧轨，是因为这两个作品叙述了特务支援课中的友情和爱情（主要还是友情啦），故事中的每一个角色甚至是NPC都缺一不可。
然后是闪轨，我只能用两个词来描述它————“人生” “成长“。从1代的校园生活到2代的寻找朋友然后拯救世界，虽然感觉有点假，但是叙述了琳恩的艰难成长过程，最后克洛死的时候，并不是觉得简简单单的失去了一个好同学好朋友，更是为克洛的悲惨过去感到悲愤。
然后最后是闪3，我特别喜欢这种主角成长后的故事，有一种自己也随着时间的推移自己确确实实得也成长了许多。从新vii班上也看到了旧vii班的影子，然后是是第二章“相克的克洛斯贝尔”，我真的觉得falcom的这一作品跟前作连接的真的是恰到好处。二章快完的时候，我终于知道为什么闪3会有yuna这个普通人的故事了，就是为了铺垫克州的故事。后来知道特务支援课，风之剑圣和银都被政府关了起来的时候，我不仅跟yuna一样为特务支援课的遭遇感到悲愤，另外想到的却是风之剑圣的女儿，那个住在医院里的盲人小女孩，名字忘记了（好像叫夜夜），她爸爸被关了起来，那她怎么办！！（闪3只玩到了这里，只能讲这么多）

我也看很多人说闪轨系列不如女神异闻录5，我并不否认女神异闻录5是个好游戏，因为我也曾经为之动情过。我最想说这两个游戏有什么可比性。两个不同的世界观，一个是从社会现象反应出的社会观，另一个是凭空虚构的世界观。各自都有各自的有点。就比如我拿红楼梦和西游记比，你觉得哪个好，是不是？

我不是falcom的无脑粉，我是一个有心有脑的正常人。

If you're a fan of JRPGs, you owe it to yourself to play this game. Excellent gameplay, story, characters, and a fantastic soundtrack make for one of the best JRPGs on Steam. While it is part of the overarcing Legend of Heroes: Trails in/of X series, Steel is able to stand on its own enough that you don't really need to have played the previous games (Trails in the Sky FC/SC/The 3rd, along with the yet-unlocalized Zero/Ao no Kiseki) to enjoy the story/game. 35503567.review:
Well, I got hooked. I am a fan now. I just finished my first playthrough.

Positives:
- Storyline. The character building is solid and consistent.
- Dungeons/Field variability and length. You can be inside a castle, on a field, or underground, all have been rendered to provide a unique gameplay.
- Difficulty. Not overly-grindlike on normal, can be forgiving for a beginner on the genre.
- Translation. No awkward language shift noted.

Negatives:
- Depth. Probably, because it's early in the Cold Steel saga, I find that some character is very one dimensional, clichéd, gimmicky, and just poorly written.
- Achievements. Now, this might be my problem, though, my hours and medals both won't update.

I will definitely recommend this game to any JRPG fan while waiting for the sequel myself.

35244380.review:
I found the anime high school tropes fairly uninteresting, and by the time the plot started picking up steam literally at the final hour of the game it transforms into a mecha anime and then ends on a cliffhanger.

One major thing I missed from the earlier Trails games was the expressive 2D portraits for dialogues, which are now replaced by blank-faced dolls of the CG characters which have no personality when speaking. I also felt the NPC stories and such were much less developed and lacking compared to FC and SC, and overall the repetitive nature of the school trips / anime school structure of the gameplay dragged on too long. I hope the second game shakes that formula up the way the ending seems to hint at.

Combat was still the least interesting bit of the game, honestly, and the fact that the player knows more at this point (if they've played the previous Trails games) about what's going on in Zemuria than the main characters makes it frustrating that so little new info or significant development on that point happens in the plot here until literally the final few minutes.

Overall, I have to say this is my least favorite of the Trails games so far, though I'll give the second Steel game a try before I decide whether the series has really jumped the shark for me or not. 

For folks invested in the story since FC/SC/3rd, Steel will not build on much of what those games have laid as a story foundation. I'd almost recommend waiting for all 3 of Steel's games to be released before playing them (as maybe together they will progress the story more significantly than just this one does).

35205176.review:
玩了很久的游戏，今天终于通关了，感慨良多。

首先硬性评析一下游戏各方面素质：

剧情：9.5分
音乐：10分
画面：9.5分
人设：9.5分
标签：大爱，超赞，感动，轨迹一生推！！！

从《空之轨迹》开始喜欢上了轨迹系列，喜欢它可爱的画面，炫丽的技能，感动的瞬间，细腻的描写，激动人心的剧情，而这种特色在《闪之轨迹》里不仅完美地保留了下来，反而更上了一层楼。

本部作品从一开始就牢牢吸引了我，Falcom公司一如既往地以交通工具的方式缓缓展开故事，一步一步娓娓道来。春暖花开的季节里，在命运的安排下，来自不同家庭背景特性各异的少男少女们集聚一堂，从此展开了他们之间有趣而又感动的羁绊。此后在平凡的日子里他们之间的关系愈来愈亲密，回忆不断地交织，最终演变成了难以割舍的友谊与恋情。

剧情非常充实，完全对得起价格：做各种小任务，却会不经意间被卷入一些重大事件，一段紧张的故事之后，又会有几天轻松欢快的学院生活......

令我印象最深刻的当属高原之行，白天策马奔腾，夜晚仰望星空，狂野与唯美并行，留下了一个个感动的瞬间。

进入终章之后，原以为游戏就差不多会在舒缓的节奏中拉上帷幕......没想到之后居然高潮迭起，从学院祭上各种趣味小活动，以及后期随着剧情突如其来的新战斗方式，都无不令人拍手称快！

总体来说，非常喜爱并强烈推荐《闪之轨迹》这款游戏。它让我重新燃起了JRPG的热情，非常期待之后的第二部、第三部！
