35178102.review:
If you've played the Trails in the Sky series, then you know what to expect.

Excelent and polished fighting mechanics with a little extra flare added here and there compared to the TS series. Other than some small changes to orbments, arts, and extra in-battle mechanics, it's pretty much the same as in TS.
Music is top notch and matches the scenes pretty well, although I noticed they reused a couple tracks from the TS series (might be a reaccuring theme, I dont really know).
There is a configuration panel at the very beginning before you start the game which really helps out with optimization and detailing its "speed up" feature.

For 90% of the game, the storytelling is on point. The areas you visit, the characters, the world all feel pretty real and connected. The world itself is the same as in TS and seems to take place a couple years after the end of that series, so they make a couple nice cameos to some previous TS characters. The main characters feel pretty complex. None of them are 2D and I eventually end up liking them all despite hating a couple at the beginning. Although a lot of the side characters suffer as a result, but that's fine in my book. My only complaint with the story is how abruptly it turns 180 near the end, as if the writers wanted the big reveal to be the biggest plot twist they could possibly make with as little connection to the rest of the story (at least not in this game). 

The biggest con I can think of right now is that, being a JRPG, there's a huge number of completely hidden side quests and hidden requirements for certain achievements that are literally impossible to find without a detailed guide (unless you scour all the areas throughly after each event and listen closely to every detail). Some of them are so obscure that they dont register as a quest even when you officially start it, and will only tell you about it after you complete it. Granted, this is nothing new in JRPGs and for anyone who isnt a completionist, it shouldnt really matter in the end.

Another thing I hated from the very beginning was the English Dub and the fact that there is no option for Japanese Dub. Luckily you can turn off all voices, which is what I was used to from the TS series so that was quickly resolved. 

In the end, this is a great JRPG that is excellent in most of its presentation. However, it is a 3 part series, so be prepared for a huge cliffhanger and be prepared to buy the next 2 games whenever they get around to translating them.

35151551.review:
This series (and Trails in the Sky) has been a huge and pleasant surprise for me, a long-time RPG fan. Legend of Heros exists since the late 80s, but it never gathered much of a following in the West. Gladly, XSEED has done an excellent job with the localization of the Kiseki series, so the following is starting to gather up!

About this game especifically, I absolutely recommend it. There are a lot of JRPGs out there that follow an anime-esque storyline, but few write them as engaging and with so compeling characters as Nihon Falcom did with this game and its sequel. The story is great, you CARE for your companions and for the political situation of Erebonia and its people. Even NPCs are compelling.

Gameplay is also great (even if a little dated).

On the "negative" side, the game is LONG (prepare to stay with it for around 80 to 90 hours), it starts very slow (be patient, it's worth it! Every good book starts developing slowly) and some main quests can drag. 

Nothing to make me dislike this game at any front. Utterely recommended!

这大概是我在steam上通的第一个大型单机游戏了。等了n年闪轨终于登陆pc，简直泪流满面。时间线和零轨碧轨是同步的，只不过镜头移动到了帝国这边。然而因为时间太久了我把零轨碧轨剧情都忘得差不多了，本作里提到克州发生的事件让我有点对应不上QAQ。
一周目刚通关，游戏里显示的游戏时间是96小时，steam这里显示110小时……可能把挂机时间也算上了吧。。。二周目玩一会儿就能拿100小时的成就了哈哈。一周目玩的时间这么长，可能是因为人物对话率高吧，可能有80%以上了。强迫症，剧情每推进一点就把地图上所有人都对话一遍。不过这也是轨迹系列的优点，npc的故事是随着主线发展而变化的。
本作主要讲述了一群二代们的学院生活，最后[strike] 开高达拯救世界的故事 [/strike] 。嗯，主角是八叶一刀[spoiler] 克妻 	[/spoiler]流的传人也就算了，未来剑圣还不行吗，还能开高达……这光环就过分了吧。。。
一周目用的是3dm的3.2版汉化补丁，嗯，并非完美汉化，但是也能用。贴吧dalao科洛蒂亚公主似乎做出了完美汉化补丁的样子，还没开始玩或者不满意游侠和3dm汉化的小伙伴可以去试试，二周目我是打算换补丁了。
第一次写评测，就酱。开二周目去了。

35112264.review:
Dont be fooled by my low game time. I have about 80 hours clocked in on the ps3.
What can i say? I buy very few games on retail price even less so when i already own them on another platform, but this game is truly something else.
In a world littered with flashy rpgs like Final Fantasy's which prefer style over substance, this game truly stands out above them all. Not just this but the entire Legend of Heroes series, though talking about them all would derail this review.
What this game shines at, is its world building, the story takes time to unfold, you are gradually filled in how this fantasy world works.
You have a stellar cast of characters. None of them feel like placeholders, each person, each supporting character has a unique story and background defining them. 
The characters traits may look cliched but when executed perfectly they shine through and through.
You get to live a school life not entirely dissimilar to Persona, you do quests, you go out exploring the world, you get entangled in political and civil unrest, explore the country of Erebonia and its heirarchy system, uncover a dark conspiracy, trust me, by the time you're done you'll be left wanting for more, which is a good thing cuz the sequel will be coming to pc in 2018.
Plus the pc version is THE definitive version. Upgraded graphics (I seriously love the effort they put in the launcher, each option shows you a screenshot of what effect it has on the game) , turbo mode allowing you to fast forward cutscenes and battles (Wouldnt recommend doing the former) and about 5000 extra voiced lines exclusive for the pc version.
No japanese audio though, but the falcom server on discord has an unofficial japanese audio patch with instructions that you can use. Though personally I dont need it cuz the english voice cast is amazing!
All in all, a solid 11/10 . Highly recommended game!

UPDATE: There are several other dlc costumes locked in the game. However there is no way to get them legally since probably XSEED couldnt acquire the licenses for them. Those files are lying dormant in the game. 
The only way I have found to obtain them is on the pirated version with the 'dlc unlocker' . It can net you 5 extra costume sets namely  'Jenis Uniform, Reverse Uniform, Black Uniform, Mishy Uniform, and Lawson Uniform' They are simple recolors of the standard uniform and are fully translated too.
If you love to support XSEED like me yet still want those costumes, do what I did. Use the dlc unlocker on the pirated version and get to the Old Schoolhouse at the beginning, at which point, redeem all the dlcs from the dlc tab to add them in your inventory and then save. Now use this save with the steam version and those costumes will be there in your inventory.
Unfortunately they'll be gone again in a NG+ so if you want them you'll have to repeat the process.

PS3/Vita版の正当リマスター版（日本語ボイスなし）です。
ゲーム自体はPS3/Vita版と同じですし、他の方も触れているので、システム関係についてコメントします。

[u]■映像設定[/u]
プリセットが4つあり、そこから個別に設定も可能（設定画面も日本語です）。その他、
[list]
[*]起動時のロゴやOPムービーをスキップする設定も可能。
[*][b]視野角を広くできる（引きカメラが可能）。[/b]
[*]画質はPS3を上回る設定（ただしモデリングとモーションは元のままなので、まあ…）だけでなく、下回る設定も可能。
[/list]
なお、ボタンアサイン機能はありません。XboxコントローラだとBボタンが決定ボタンです（日本語版のみ？）。

[u]■読み込み[/u]
読み込みがなくなり、非常に快適です。

新たに搭載されたターボモード（R2）は、
[list]

と、かなり快適さに寄与しています。

衣装などは残念ながら別途有料。ただし、PS3/VitaでDLC扱いになっているものの一部は本体に同梱されています。同梱されているDLCは以下のとおり。

35014656.review:
Join Rean along with the other students of Class VII from Thors Military Academy as they travel through Erebonia on their field studies to solve issues for locals and discover who they are and their place in the political world before a darker more serious story unfolds and explodes. 

Unlike somewhat similar franchises and titles, ToCS focuses more on the global political and military elements throughout the story helping players absorb the world better instead of fading into the background as an afterthought. But the real pull is how lifelike and different all of the characters are; Rich, poor, noble bloodline, and commonfolk. Each character and NPC typically will have a different background or attitude bringing about a more believeable world.

I also like how each new installment is not a brand new game in a brand new world (or distant timeline) but a few years into the timeline so players can see familiar faces facing different struggles in a changing, evolving world.


Oh and the PC port is absolutely flawless. 
Running this in 3440x1440 when it was originally optimized for the PS Vita is insane.

34992100.review:
Отличная jrpg, но понравится не всем. Игра сильно ориентирована на историю, мир и персонажей, причем способ подачи взят прямиком из классических романов: объемная экспозиция, тонны описаний, порой утопающих в мелочах, и мееедлено двигающийся основной сюжет. Вас ждет куча (кучище!) неторопливых диалогов, превосходно проработанный мир без деления на абсолютно белое и абсолютно черное, добротные персонажи не с одномерными характерами и самобытная боевая система, почти избавленная от гринда (и это в jrpg, хех).

[b][u]Самое важное предупреждение касательно этой игры:[/u][/b] чтобы поиграть, игроку нужно знать английский по меньшей мере на уровне intermediate (или даже upper intermediate) просто для того, чтобы понимать, что происходит, куда идти, и кто вообще все эти люди. Стрелочки-указателя зачастую нет, смысл заданий нужно выуживать из диалогов, если не вникать в слова персонажей, они (персонажи) будут казаться плоскими, а история - водой. Если вы не готовы к километрам английского текста, покупать не стоит.

[u]Графика[/u] - уровень современных мобильных игр, не выше, оттого многие вещи изображены весьма условно. Но стоит отдать должное: при скудных выразительных возможностях разработчики постарались хоть как-то оживить деталями камерный мир, придать ему масштаб. Каждый персонаж обязательно что-нибудь скажет в диалоге, и это "что-нибудь" постоянно меняется по мере продвижения по сюжету.
[u]Музыка[/u] - ничего выдающегося, есть пара запоминающихся композиций. Озвучка - сама по себе неплоха, но озвучены лишь самые важные диалоги, да и то не все. Спорно.
[u]Геймплей[/u] - боевая система перекочавала из предыдущих игр серии, хуже не стала, нововведения есть (combat links), но они по большому счету бессмысленны, поскольку представляют собой случайные бонусы, от которых тактику не построить. Кастомизация персонажей (рпг-элемент) в наличии, более того - она действительно работает, персонажей можно обвесить по-разному, и это оказывает сильное влияние на тактику ведения боя. Локации кишкообразные (следствие слабой технологической базы), исследование поощряется, но мест для исследования раз два и обчелся.
[u]Лояльность к новичкам в серии[/u] - все сделано для того, чтобы новичку в серии было комфортно: лор прописан превосходно, все значимые элементы мира разъяснены, если читать внимательно, неясных моментов нет.
[u]Минусы:[/u]
- Цепочка из диалогов и катсцен может достигать получаса реального времени, в течение которого нет возможности ни сохраниться, ни прерваться. Эта особенность тянется еще с первой игры, ума не приложу, почему не исправлено.
- На нормальном уровне сложности игра не предоставляет игроку никакого челенджа за исключением нескольких мест в конце игры.
- Графон не ахти, да.
- 3 вылета за прохождение.
- Вся игра - один большой пролог. История порезана на 3 части, 2 из которых нужно ждать.
- 6 глав с повторяющимся построением делает часть сюжетных поворотов весьма предсказуемыми

34961495.review:
Trails of Cold Steel is an excellent game which I highly recommend. Usually one expects to find characters with a lot of depth, a meticulously detailed world and a highly nuanced political story of conflicting sides in a book. Trails of Cold Steel does the first two of these things excellently despite being a game, while it surpasses what a book could do in the third. 

Political conflicts are best understood by listening to the inhabitants of the world in which it is taking place. A book cannot do this as well as an RPG due to the fact what these people think will mostly come in the form of exposition. Meandering from person to person simply wouldn't work in a book. However, speaking to NPC's inhabiting a town, who all tell you their take on what is happening, who's side they are on, and what is on their mind works very well for this. Trails of Cold Steel makes full use of this advantage RPG's possess. Each NPC in every town leads their own life, and they all have dialogue which updates between every major story event. In addition to this, there are many quests, some optional, some required, which also contribute to building what feels like a world of real people.

The obvious drawback to all of this is of course that the story is very slow-paced. It is not until the end of chapter 3 that things starts speeding up, although it certainly doesn't slow down. In addition to this the characters at the start of the game appear to be quite cliche. As the game carries on, it will become clear that these characters have more than enough depth to them, but both of these factors combined can make Trails of Cold Steel hard to get in to. 

In addition to writing - its main selling point, Trails of Cold steel has quite a satisfactory combat system. It is different enough from other JRPG's, while there there is more than enough variety. My main issue would be that many bosses rely heavily on inflicting status conditions. This makes the combat a little easy when using the correct accessories which block these conditions, while it can very hard when these are lacking. 

Finally the music of Trails of Cold Steel is fantastic, and it is one of my favorite soundtracks from any game I've played. I would suggest to simply look up some of the songs on YouTube and listen for yourself. Some personal favorites of mine are "Don't Be Defeated By a Friend", "Crimson Wings, A New Wind" and "Atrocious Raid". (Be cautious looking at songs from the sequel, Trails of Cold Steel II, because the cover of this album has a major spoiler for this game!)

Overall, if you are fond of story rich RPG's, and can handle the slow pacing this game starts off with, I'm confident you'll enjoy Trails of Cold Steel immensely. I certainly did.

34955443.review:
So first of all this game is extremely linear with a very repeptitive schedule. But having said that, I enjoyed this game thoroughly. The voice acting is pretty standard for an English dub but I was able to live through it. The gameplay is actually really cool and can be broken if using certain exploits.

Would I recommend this game to people? Sure, but this is more or a prologue to the 2nd game and will make you want to play the 2nd game straight away(if you enjoy this game anyway). I am currently hanging for the next game to come out as the ending left me extremely intrigued. 

Solid JRPG 8/10
Pros:
Decent cast of characters even if some are annoying
Difficulty can spike if unprepared
Decent setup for the 2nd game
Easy to learn combat, hard to master if new to the series, well for me anyway
NG+
Fast travelling
Runs very smooth with no crashes, for me anyway

Cons:
Voice acting
Dialogue goes for too long sometimes without any plot relevence
Strict repeatable schedule
Talk to every NPC always after every little scene to make sure you get everything

34874658.review:
The game in itself is quite entertaining on three points.
1-The balance between battles, exploration, and story events is excellent. It helps me actually to plan my day as to know when to stop haha! But more than that, there is diversity. Its not a game all about action, or all about this or that. Sure I would have enjoyed more puzzles personnaly, but one cannot have everything in one game (a pizza cannot have everything in it, would be way to thick if we tried to represent EVERY trends in one dish). You hardly get bored of something unless you are at the very end of it, which is good also. Sometimes you need to feel like you want to move on in order to really enjoy the transition when it happens.

2-Combining different elements. If we were to ask me if I prefer the Trails in the sky or cold steel, I would say they are different enough to be enjoyable in their respective strong points. I do prefer for example the system in which depending on the ammount of quartz one puts on a character the spells change accordingly in the first serie. However, I enjoy alot if not more the combination of upgrading your quartz and of leveling them. It adds some customization to your characters. Its only annoying to having your characters reequip special quartz because they got unequipped simply because they didn't take part in a chapter. But oh well. One could also argue that with every new quartz you get, you tend to change their build anyways so might as well do it. Cooking and grinding is great. You don<t really grind materials as much as you grind the sepith which in turn you convert into mira in order to buy ingredients. All that is nice and relaxing. No pressure to do some HEAVY grinding, but still enough diversity in the ingredients to buy stuff. The different results is a plus compared to the first trails in the sky (have yet to play chapters 2-3).

3-The approach to the story line is refreshing. Yeah, its linear, but having the socializing phase between the field studies is a great way to delve into the immediate lore. What I mean by immediate lore is not background information like what you get from reading novels or checking the library, which is good also especially if you like the sense of continuity with the previous serie. By immediate I am referring to things which are not important for the scenario, nor for the link between games, but has valuable information on your surroundings, your characters. I think the lack of romance till the end of the game leaves an open door for the second chapter which I hope will come soon on steam. According to some reviews I watched, on the second chapter it is less linear and choices do matter. Its great to keep things up your sleeves so no complaints from me (I am not that interested in hunting romance in a game actually, but this is my first review so I try to describe everything and I know for some its a plus).

Those were, in my opinion, the strongest points.

Now, three good points.

1-Story. The scenario is really interesting and though its slow at first, it gets quickly out of hand and I like the idea you know not much till later on when other questions replace those you finally got an answer. Sadly, stereotypes tend to dilute a little bit the originality. The noble faction is an interesting enemy but their soldiers are just plain stupid. Sometimes I feel like its the overemphasis on the eyes and the evil laugh you often find in mangas or animes (as if a bad guy will laugh ominously all the time). Some time a cliche is great, and truth be told this games can exploit that alot in the good way, but that all the provincial soldiers are self-centered as they are snf do full of themselves, erm.... its like they all have one personnality. But beside that point, I found myself intrigued more and more as the chapters went by. The dilemmas are well balanced, not too much on the idealistic side of things. I like the fact they did such a great job in giving unique personnalities to important characters or side characters and not being afraid of using them as spices in their story dish. Its worth mentionning that many subtle details will slip before you on the first play, and certainly when I will replay it right after finishing it I will enjoy the details of the plot even more.

2-The quest system is good. but to my opinion I do prefer the relation of Estelle to her quests than of Rean to his. He does not react so much, okay its his personnality, but he tends to be self sufficient a little. Estelle needed the help of Joshua to either calm her down or fill in where she needed help. Here, Rean is always on the right AND the righteous path. However, that we have different types of quest is a boon. First, you have those of Thors, given to you by the studen council. Second, you have those given to you in your field studies. And finally there are those hidden quests. They are all different.

3-The fishing club. Too bad you cannot choose your club, but at least we have a mini-game which provides rewards and patience. In my opinion it could have been more developped but at least it follows you from the academy to your field studies, giving you a well deserved break from running all over the place (AND GIVING YOU FREE CP YAY!!). Gives you also the urge to fill your fish encyclopedia ;)

There are things which I personnaly dislike.

1-The equipment shop seems rather linear. Not much diversity, not customization of weapons. I thought at first that the U-Materia and the option of customizing would ACTUALLY give you the pleasure of either upgrading your weapons or enchancing them, but its quite limited. You CAN upgrade them, but often you can simply buy the newer version in a store and both ways are equal in benefits. No rewards in customizing.

2-Lack of character developpement with Rean. From the start to the end, he is always the same. When he seems to think alot and go on a re-examination of himself and of the world, most of the time its by reminding himself of events or ineractions he already had before. Truth be told, he does more often refere to events and interactions during the game, but they seldom have a lasting impact on him. How about a character that learns to discern? He already knows how to from the start, and already good enough that he does not really require more learning in that departement. He spends most of his time helping others developpe, but others don't tend to contribute to his slow growth.



So, should I recommend this game? Depends. If you like solid character growth you may be disappointed and I would rather recommend the first serie. However, this one gives alot in compensation to the other characters (Fie and Macchias being two good examples). Quick dip in the action of the story, nah, it starts pretty slow at first, but honestly I oftend get tired of games who throw you right away in the plot cause you get tired of it. Giving some timo to just get used to the culture IN the game is in my opinion a characteristic of a good plot. Graphics may not be the best, but I don<t care, they are good enough so you don<t bother and actually, I prefer a game with better scenarios and great playability over super fancy visuals. 

In my opinion, these games (cold steel and heroes trails in the sky chapter 1) made me discover a great RPG company which is Falcom. They are quite devoted to give a detailed world in which we play,

34873514.review:
Masterful:
- PC port is perhaps the best port of a game from inferior hardware so far
- K+M controls
- turbo mode
- the only jRPG I played where english voiceover isn't cringeworthy

Good:
- leveldesign
- fishing minigame capped so fish doesn't respawn endlessly and you can't grind it
- quite a few bosses are challenging on your first normal playthrough (if you won't abuse arc craft)
- story twists

Also good, but Trails in the Sky has much better:
- characters, villains, drama and general story progression
- music
- quartz system, there is no "sepith tetris" in Cold Steel

Bad:
- grinding is necessary for $, achievements and leveling links/masterquartz
- many optional and all hidden quests are timed
- graphics is just a bit better than decade(s) old Gothic
- cooking is not RPG skill but is fixed and you cannot improve it
- pixelhunt for fishing spots and smashed boxes' loot
- the concert event sucks, they should have made it better
- loading savegame from here in the sequel (not ported yet on PC, expected by the end of this year) doesn't give buffs only for all sidequests/hiddenquests finished, it also checks for your level which you need to grind up then 

Atrocious aka fire from industry whomever decided to put it in this game:
- swimming minigame which is worst QTE fest I've ever seen
- pay2win DLC (bait gems that summon a trashmob that grant tons of XP)
- NG+ is necessary to complete masterquartz collection and to see all of the most interesting bonding cutscenes


Overall, the game is good, just not as great as Trails in the Sky was. For example Trails in the Sky discouraged grinding. ToCS encourages it.

ToCS in IMO above average game, but it's inferor hardware roots didn't do it any favor, I can't call it a musthave game. If you decide to buy this game, you won't be disappointed, just don't expect a masterpiece.

[B]7/10[/B]


Additional note. There is so called super arrange version of game OST. For everyone out there who adores symphonic rock as much as I do, it is a must buy. Here's one score from it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oo7jUwMmSA8
If these arrangements were used in the game, I'd have put a better score - as these would feel like home in PC port.

34836709.review:
Trails of Cold Steel starts off confusing, you get thrown into the 'prologue' which is pretty much the main part of chapter 5.By doing this, it shows how powerful your characters will become, and yes. They do become this powerful. However i'll explain that later.
Throwing in at the deep end with no knowledge or the characters is confusing as you are constantly foreshadowing what will happen 1/2 a year down the line (in game). As it leaves you at a pretty big cliffhanger. 

When you start attending Thor's Military Academy, you come off the train and head into the city, where you'll meet quite a few main characters, bumping into a fine lady whom you will be spending a lot of time with.
Once this occurs you'll have about an hour at most of dialogue to get through. Which, does seem heavy. However the trails universe does a very good job at introducing those characters and developing them as time moves forwards.

I went into the game with no real expectations. I was looking for a good JRPG game, which I could throw my hours in over the remainder of the summer holidays.. I was and am impressed. The game lasted a hell of a long time, while. Yes, it only took  me a week. I had a lot of hours invested into this game. The main thing which I enjoy is the character development and the world building which was amazing inside of this game. 

There are a lot of main characters, so much so that you'll start to lose track of what and who they are. However, you have the handy feature of the classbook or whatever you call. WHich you have to painstakingly hand out to everyone in your class quite early on in the game. This records all the important information which you will find out about characters. This could be through the bonding events, or just general interaction. 
The flesh out the world more and more as you immerse yourself deeper and deeper into the game. With places which are mentioned early on, being places which you visit on Field Studies. You also get to learn about family members of the big 11. Along with their homes and way of life. 

You will start off hating characters. While the hate never really faded for me with Machinas. However out of the eleven characters he is the only one that I didn't like. Mainly because he's a whiney little bitch. 
However he does have his moments. Near the end.

The pacing of the game at times does get a little dull and repetitive. As you fall into the rhythm of being the student council's little fairy, doing their tasks. Beating a floor of the old school house, having a practical examination (getting your ass kicked by Sara for the most part) then off you pop onto the train to the next city where you will spend two or three days solving a relationship dilemma within your group. Since you are the almighty Rean; the loveable hellspawn decides that it's your responsibility to deal with this as she cannot be arsed. 
I digress, the structure is not very flexible as you do get into this rhythm and it's hard to get out of it.

However, Cold Steel makes up for this by having an absolute killer soundtrack. I am honestly impressed with how amazing the music was for this game. I would have the volume on full blast for the majority of this game so I could appreciate the music; as it fits the mood perfectly. However I would've liked for there to be more of a diverse set of music for each area of the game. Yes, the music is amazing. However it plays for half the chapter and doesn't change often. However, thank god it changed each chapter. 

The Combat system is very impressive. With Attacks, Magic (Arts), Crafts (Character driven abilities), the standard items and run. I threw away Magic for the most part of the game as waiting for it to activate wasn't effective and just used mainly Attacks and Crafts. Which hit harder and faster. However once I got the Adamantium Shield Art, I started using magic again as it is insanely powerful. 
The Combat system is refreshing, while it's nothing amazing, it is at least enjoyable. 

The last few chapters, I was expecting the game to end anytime then. I could see many places where they could've ended it and resumed it in the next expansion of the arc. However to my delight, it continued on for quite some time! Once I went to bed after I got into the last floor of the Old school house and decided I'd clear it tomorrow, as it must of been where the game ended. As I had a little time free in the morning... I finished the dungeon after a good number of hours... then the boss battle... then the final chapter sprang up which meant that it still wasn't down for the count.

The game ends with a cliffhanger. To my great displeasure. As I have read many reviews that even told me that there would be a cliffhanger ending. I was not happy in the slightest. I did not want this game to end. I was in the developer's pockets until the very end. While, it isn't satisfying at the least. As you get CRAZY over powered towards the end and everything starts to kick off. You find out C's identify. Which while there were many signs in the game all along, is still a shock. The capital is occupied and they're coming for Thor's. Class VII with their fearless (and clueless) leader Rean, heading out to fend off the attack until the Military can send relief. 
You fight off two enemies (Not spoiling it) and then fight C for the last time in Trails of Cold Steel I. After that, you leave. Not out of your own choice either. Flying off to the furthest place from Thor's as possible. Heading home. The game ends there. With the fleeting text from the developers to port the next game to PC. Which was enough to satisfy me.

In conclusion, this game is phenomenal. The characters are thoroughly amazing, they are fleshed out and you really get to know them. The game took me about 40 hours to complete. However, this was with the amazing feature of Turbo mode, allowing you to speed up the game to allow you to get back into the combat as quickly as possible. I had it turned on for the grand majority of the game. As it allows you to waste less time doing the side quests and running about from destination to destination. I am also ashamed to say that I found a way to go undetected by monsters that roam in the wild. Allowing me to breeze through the last dungeon. 
I would heavily recommend this game to anyone who is an avid reader of fantasy novels, as it achieves the same thing that reading can do in a short time. 
Those who love JRPGs will be in for a treat as this is the best which I have played in a long time, beating Final Fantasy X by a long run.

34835274.review:
What an absolutely incredible roller coaster ride this game has been. I haven't felt so strongly about a RPG ever since FFX and even I feel that this game may be on par with it. Before I begin my review, I just want to reiterate that although I have 96.3 hours in this game and counting, that was only through my first playthrough. How I was able to amass that much time in a game will be stated shortly. 

Character Development
Though you are introduced to an astonishing and somewhat intimidating amount of characters, each character has been developed with proper care and it isn't long until you begin to care about each of them. The characters are probably the strongest part in this game and they are all very much human. It is an absolute far cry to the last JRPG games that I played that consisted of FFXIII & FFXV along with some american RPG games that I've played such as Skyrim, and Far Cry. They also develop very realistically all having their own faults, as normal High School Kids are. And yet, their struggles are things that you care about as you get to know each of them. On you off days you are able to get to know each of your classmates, but it never seems like it drags on as you are only allowed a certain amount of bonding points per day. 

Even the NPCs you interact with seem to have very interesting stories. And It's actually probably what I spent most of my time doing in this game even though it wasn't required. The shop keepers don't just have a "shop option" in them, and you can actually get to know what their backstory is along with many of the other NPCs that you are introduced to throughout the series. All the characters, I feel, in Trails of Cold Steel added so much to the immersion. 

Story
The story starts off relatively quickly. You play in the perspective of Rean Schwarzer and you are just confused as he is in the class when he is placed in with the rest of his colorful classmates. Though each chapter is set in a school setting, the strongest part of this series come from these Field Studies that Class VII distinctly goes through. Throughout each chapter you go to these trips called field studies where you embark on other areas of the country along with subtle tidbits about the history of both the continent and your classmates. Along with these Field Studies are tasks that you do in order to A) progress the story forward & B) able to get to know the people in the city/town. And once you get to know all of the characters there, the story really starts moving along along with some mind jarring twists that even the most observant wouldn't see coming along. 

Port
The port is Fleshed out really nicely in comparison to the PSVita version and it almost makes me sad that I will probably have to wait a year or 2 before the second game comes out. I am tempted to buy the second one just on the PS3 and deal with the lower frame rathes, but to be honest the graphics wasn't something that I wasn't paying too much attention to anyways. There are some dated moments that have to do with the graphical engine at the time, that you will see as you're playing such as teleporting students or even the way characters walk may be a little jagged, but all in all it is a really clean port that I was able to run very nicely with my Asus 1070 I5 6600K which may even be overkill for a game such as this.

Sound
Almost all the cut scenes have voice lines, though they are mainly in English. Though I'm pretty sure it is possible to find a Mod for a Japanese voice acting, the English voice acting in itself is superb and that is coming from someone who has watched a long list of animes and is rather picky with the amount of Dub there is in an anime. Though be warned that according to the port, there was apparently 5,000 additional lines of text that was able to be voiced which may not be included if you were to mod this game. 

The Soundtrack in this game fits absolutely well, from rocking action to some school-appropriate subtle spring music, I felt that the music only added to the immersion as it made me feel like I was a student that was studying at Thors Military Academy, or a citizen in Erebonia. The music felt very simplified and yet absolutely fit the theme to what the developers at Falcom were aiming for. 

Overall

This was the JRPG that I've been looking for this whole time and I felt like I found an absolute jewel in this game. I also feel that this game is criminally underrated, especially since Destructoid and Famitsu gave it some subpar ratings of 7/10 and 34/40. There is a ton of replayability in this game and you can bet that I will be replaying this and reliving the days with Class VII and playing the second part of the series on the PS3 and maybe someday play it on Steam as well when it comes out on PC. 

10/10

34826941.review:
This game is amazing.  Like a 3D version of one of those really great PSone era JRPGs

Look forward to..
- A story with a ton of worldbuilding that makes you crave more.
- Deep and interesting characters.
- Writing in a JRPG that's actually good!
- A fun and satisfying turn based combat system.
- English voice acting that's really good.
- Waifus,  So many Waifus.
- A great port from console. (It's like Funcom actually cares.)


Prepare for...
- A slow start.
- Some Persona time mechanics that aren't quite as well polished.
- Much more talking than stabbing.
-  A less than ideal menu system.


This is the second time I've bought this game.  The first time was on Vita and the PC is the best place to play it by far.  The near instantaneous load times and high frame rate make a huge difference in terms of making everything just plain better.

What makes this game as good as it is, however, is the depth and quality of worldbuilding.  That is what this game is all about.  Each chapter introduces you to a new region and delves into one or two of the character's in your party.  Which will seem slow at first but after a few chapters you begin to realize that the game has tricked you into learning about it's world and it's character at a crazy level of depth.   Which it then starts using to full effect in the later parts of the story.

Then there are the characters who are universally great.  At first they just seem like a bunch of anime tropes but all of them have a twist or some sort of backstory that builds your interest in each as the game goes along.   There is no finer example of than the main character himself, Rean.  At first he just seems like a normal vanilla hero.  Until you find out he's nowhere near as normal as he seems and is every bit as deep an interesting as the rest of the cast.

So if you love old school JRPGs with a deep story and don't mind a bit of a slow burn storywise.  Get this.  It's fantastic.

34823940.review:
Sooo first review, first thing's first:

You do not need to have played the previous Trails (or in Japan "Kiseki") series; the game makes some references to those games, mostly Ao no Kiseki (Trails to Azure?); but for the most part you really won't be spoiled for those games, in fact this game was made with newcomers in mind. 

I have played the PS3 version and I can tell you if you get this, you are buying the definitive version, I cannot tell you how great it is to replay this game in 60 FPS with extra voice acting. This game, like most of XSeed's localizations: has no censorship. Unfortunately there’s no dual audio since they couldn't get it (Japanese VAs are very protective of their work, or so I'm told), however you can mod them back in, but the dub VAs are excellent! Better than your average dub, give or take; a lot of people don't like the VA for Alisa though; personally I think Laura sounds too old.

What of the gameplay though?

Well if you got that old Turn Based JRPG itch that needs to be scratched; this is the game for you. It has some of the best elements of other JRPGs old and new. 

I think the battle system is a lot like Final Fantasy X's battle system, but unlike FFX your party's positioning is taken to account on the field, so sometimes positioning is important. Crafts are unique moves that each character can use, S-Crafts/S-Breaks are your limit breaks and Arts are your spells, which take a turn to charge and a turn to cast (which makes sense IMO), but arts do not miss. 

One of the new things in this game that wasn't in previous entries is the ability to physically attack and unbalance your enemy and follow up with the party member that character who unbalanced is linked to for more damage.

My biggest disappointment though with this game; is that Falcom dumbed down the orbment system compared to Trails in the Sky (also on Steam). Orbments are the game's explanation of the type of technology of how they can run vehicles, appliances, guns, cast Arts (spells), etc. What your characters use are combat orbments (The ARCUS in this game's case) which either increases each of your character's parameters such as increased Attack or HP and Arts such as Fire Bolt (basic fire spell) and Tear (basic healing spell) and later on a chance to inflict status on you opponant. 

You can give spells to any character, although not all character's stats are the same, so ot's better to have offensive Arts to characters with a high ATS (Arts Attack) stat! This is done by inserting what is known as Quartz refined from sepith (dropped from enemies, which you could excange for cash, but I don't recommend) into your ARCUS orbments. In Trails in the Sky, Quartz has a value and that is determined by what you can cast. In Cold Steel: what you see is what you get.

This game’s music is exceptional. I put it up there of what Square Enix, Capcom, Konami makes. Yes it can be that amazing. Falcom always has good music in their games. I still listen to them. [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R1tI_idiwnQ]Glint of Cold Steel (Main battle music)[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X1bNrqTXacU]Eliminate Crisis![/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L2OBpsUK5PU]Exceed![/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LO9M2NqSf9A](a favourite, IMO underrated) Through the Canyon Road[/url] and [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C4JXuHiSPiU]Into the Abyss[/url]; but stay away from Cold Steel II's music! The album art is a BIG spoiler; you have been warned.

This game is also Story heavy; were talking long cutscenes and not every scene is voiced, but we’re talking War and Peace in terms of how big this games dialogue is. I will say this, after the opening scene, the game does start off slow, because of world building and character development; this story is a time investment that WILL pay off; I guarantee you. As you advance the story, like Sky; NPCs usually have something new to say and usually have their own stories going on; this is what I mean by War and Peace, a lot of dialogue is optional. That's how detailed this game's world is. Playing this game on New Game Plus is also worth it because you can also pick up subtle foreshadowing and hints, that you will definitely miss the first time playing and you can carry over your items and character’s levels – if you so wish.

If you like this game and plan to get the Cold steel II, which will be coming out on Steam soon (as I write this, it’s not out yet on Steam), make sure you have a complete game save file. You’ll get some nice items by how much AP you get in this game, as well as carry over character relationships.

34797400.review:
This game singlehandedly sets the standard for all future Japanese PC ports. By recruiting optimization modder Durante to actually provide optimizations and post launch support, Xseed has proven that PC porting isn't as expensive or difficult as major publishers like Square Enix pretends it is. On top of optimizations are PC exclusive features like Turbo Mode, an FOV slider, and autosaves. Xseed and Falcom are proving to be the CD Projekt RED of JRPGs, and their games happen to be of that quality as well.

As with every Trails game, this game is just as phenominal as the Trails in the Sky trilogy was. It's one of the only JRPGs I could ever immediately start a NG+ on minutes after the credits roll. The characters are well written and fleshed out, the world is meticulously handcrafted to be unique and interesting, and the major story beats sets up the incredible sequel very well.

This is an excellent game to get into the Trails franchise. It was designed with newcomers in mind, yet still retains everything veterans love about the franchise. The amount of quality hours you can put into this game makes the full asking price worth it, and all purchases of this game is directly making a statement about what PC JRPG players want out of their ports.

34744396.review:
I enjoyed this game a lot.  It is one of my top ten favorite games of all time.  I'm a big fan of the Trails series and this ranks second among the Trails games for me, just behind Trails in the Sky SC.  I highly recommend it.

The highlights of this game for me were the story with all its twists & turns and the character growth throughout the game.  The writing is top notch.  Like a good mystery, all the clues are there, but I was still surprised by the story several times.  And every time, it was great to see how the story changed while also thinking about the clues I didn't recognize when I first saw them.

At the beginning of the story, I didn't like most of the characters.  I thought that would make it a rough game to get through.  But most of them show a lot of growth throughout the game and I ended up liking almost all of them by the ending credits.  I can't wait to see them continue their growth in the next game.

I thought the English voice acting was generally very good and helped communicate the characters' personalities and their growth.  The actresses voicing Sara and Millium were fantastic throughout the game, with great delivery.  The actress voicing Fie showed a lot of subtlety in her delivery, showing Fie's growth in the game.

There is a surprising amount of really funny humor in the game.  Like a lot of other things in these games, it is a really slow burn.  Sometimes the payoff to the joke comes entire chapters after the joke is set up.  But I laughed harder at this game than almost any other game I've played.

The graphics are much improved from Trails in the Sky, but don't compare to higher end modern games.  They are still very well done and functional, though.  I never had any problems with them.

The music was well done and memorable, but didn't come close to the music in Trails in the Sky for me.

The controls are very easy and fluid.  I played the entire game with a laptop keyboard and trackpad and never had any difficulties.

I encountered an occasional crash on earlier versions, but none in any of the more recent versions.

I play games to relax and I found this gaming experience to be very relaxing.  I can't comment on the challenge of the game other than to say there are several difficulty levels and lots of gameplay choices you can make if you want more or less challenge.

34737663.review:
I hadn't played a JRPG in years before picking this up, but I liked Trails in the Sky on the PSP so I decided to give it a go. I got hooked and played it almost nonstop until completion. My reaction to Trails of Cold Steel is 95 percent positive with just a few minor issues.

GAMEPLAY: Classic turn-based JRPG gameplay with light amount of Persona-style social sim elements. The devs clearly played Persona games and tried to incorporate a few similar mechanics. Combat has enough depth to keep you engaged, though as with most of these games, the fighting does get tedious at certain points. Please note that you spend pretty much the entire game locked within a framework of attending school, following a set schedule, and the progression is very linear. You can't explore wherever you want, whenever you want, like in some other JRPGs. Personally I thought it was an interesting way to structure the game, and I enjoyed it.

STORY/WORLD: Most of the characters are likable versions of the usual stereotypes: the upper-class snob, the nerdy girl with glasses (and always with the biggest rack. What's up with that, Japan?), the tomboyish warrior girl, etc. Your main character is a level-headed guy who reluctantly takes on the role of leader and develops strong emotional bonds with all of his classmates. In my opinion the character interactions are the best part of this game. A lot of the character development and world-building comes through playing the optional quests, so I would highly recommend not skipping those. The main story involves political and military intrigue and is well done but not particularly groundbreaking. The world itself is expansive and interesting with tons of lore. Note that this game tells only half of the story and ends on a cliffhanger. Expect to buy the upcoming (on PC) sequel if you want to complete the game's story.

GRAPHICS: Well, it's a port of a Vita game. It looks like a port of a Vita game. For what it is, it runs great on high settings, and my PC is middle-grade at best. The final dungeon and boss are pretty spectacular-looking.

MUSIC: I freaking love the music in this game. Equal to or better than Trails in the Sky. More mellow than Ys soundtracks but with plenty of memorable tunes you will find yourself humming later.

REPLAYABILITY: There is a game plus mode after you complete it the first time, which allows you to carry over some elements from your previous game (which you get to choose - it gives you a set number of points with which to "buy" keeping your stats, or money, or items, etc.) Pretty cool idea. I'll probably play the game plus on hard mode at some point.

FINAL NOTE: DO NOT play Trails of Cold Steel on easy mode! I started on easy mode and found that it was such an utter cakewalk that I abandoned my game and started over on normal mode. You can't switch it during a playthough. Even normal mode is pretty easy.

34736332.review:
Nihon Falcom does it again!

Another amazing RPG made its way to PC and I couldn't be happier. Thank you for making this such a beautiful and smooth PC port, there's not enough of them these days.

10/10 Music - The music is epic and extremely well done. I find myself paying more attention to the music than playing the game sometimes.

9/10 Characters - The characters for the most part are great. They're voice acted very well and leave you wanting more. As you discover their backgrounds you quickly realize they're not who you thought they were. Every JRPG needs a Tsundere Twin Tailed girl, and Alisa fits the bill perfectly. Easily one of my favorites. 

8/10 Story - The story for me felt slow to progress, but that may partially be my fault. Every time I entered a new area or the day changed, I'd go around and exhaust every NPC's dialogue and read every book I can find. I was very immersed into the story and kept wanting to learn more. I won't spoil anything for you.

10/10 Performance - Never before have I seen a JRPG with so many graphics options with descriptions and visual representations of what each setting actually does. I was completely blown away by this. The game performed extremely well and I was able to hold a consistent 90-100 FPS on highest settings 1920x1080. A PC port done right in my opinion.

This is another solid entry for the "Legend of Heroes" series, and while it may be older, it's new to me. I'm a PC gamer, so I never experienced the older PlayStation version of this game. Until a game hits PC it stays off my radar. Looking forward to the port of Cold Steel 2 and the eventual release, translation and port of Cold Steel 3. 

Considering how much gameplay per dollar spent you get here, this game is absolutely worth buying even at full price. If you can get it on sale, even better. You can tell that the developers put in the time and effort on this release. They deserve your money!

34708504.review:
🕹️- Diga NÂO aos games giveaways, ou custando 2,20, pois games de extrema excelência, ainda existem. The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel é um jogaço fenomenal de Jrpg \ fantasia de encher os olhos com a sua absoluta grandeza. 

🕹️- The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel conta a história de um jovem chamado Rean Schwarzer que se torna um novo estudante da Academia Militar chamada Thors.

🕹️- Situada no Império Ereboniano, a Academia Militar Thors criou uma turma nova, chamada de Classe VII, que é composta por estudantes de ambos os setores financeiros, dos mais simples aos mais nobres. 

🕹️- Sendo assim, Rean Schwarzer se torna o representante da turma, e passa a ser na maior parte do tempo, o responsável por tentar estábilizar os problemas governamentais que estão causando a desordem e chegando a começar algumas guerras com outros países, e ainda tendo que tentar proteger o seu país.

🕹️- Por esse motivo, a classe VII, passa a ser a turma de destaque da Academia Militar, por conseguirem administrar, os problemas externos, problemas com os alunos das outras classes, e os problemas pessoais relacionados aos próprios parceiros de classe. 

🕹️- Onde uns julgam os outros por causa de suas origens, porem é a classe mais brilhante, inteligente, empolgante e emocionante, que fez de Trails of Cold Steel, ser o melhor game da série The Legend of Heroes.

🕹️- Negativo - Tem um fim

🕹️- Positivo - Tem uma continuação

[h1]No geral, The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel é um esplendor que ilumina o bom gosto gamer.

Nota - 10 / 10 para sempre

34703236.review:
Having just finished my third back-to-back playthrough of this game, I figured I should give it a positive review here. I honestly wasn't sure if the Cold Steel series would reach Steam, but I'm certainly glad it did. 

First, the battle system is great. Having played Trails in the Sky FC and SC before this, I was already familiar with the Trails combat system, but combat links, master quartz, and just being in 3D added another level of strategy to battles. The normal difficulty of Cold Steel felt a lot easier than normal did in Trails in the Sky, but I didn't really mind. If you want a challenge, though, hard or nightmare is probably the way to go. 

Second, I really enjoyed the cast of characters. Sure, a lot of them start out being kinda cliche (the tsundere, the stuck-up noble, the loner, etc), but as the story progresses, they kinda break out of those stereotypes somewhat. It's also interesting watching them overcome their differences and learn to work together as a team.

Lastly, I really enjoyed the story of it. I like that you don't really know any more about what is going on than the members of your class do. Also, I really enjoyed how the school setting was done in this game. I've played several other games with a school setting, but this is the first one I've played where I actually felt like I was part of this school rather than just an observer. I also enjoy how events of the previous games are occasionally mentioned in passing. It really helps to connect all the games.

I can't wait until Cold Steel II is released! Hopefully Cold Steel III makes it to Steam, as well, along with some of the other games like Zero no Kiseki and Ao no Kiseki.

34678083.review:
[h1]Likes:[/h1]
[b]O[/b] One of the best PC port with additional graphic settings, additional English voice lines, new turbo mode, and selectable controller prompts (XBox 360 or Dualshock 3 scheme).
[b]O[/b] Excellent world building and intriguing political plot with numerous casts. Perfectly relaxing plots at times and high tension moments are well written.
[b]O[/b] Great classic turn based RPG combat system, with tons of hidden quests and additional game mechanics. Each playable character is unique, mechanic wise, and is customizable. No level grinding required to progress through the story.
[b]O[/b] Play time can easily clocked over 60 hours, with even longer play time for completionist.
[b]O[/b] Great soundtracks overall.

[h1]Dislike:[/h1]
[b]X[/b] While most of the main casts are well developed, they are extremely JRPG tropey with some sort of tragic back stories.
[b]X[/b] Original Japanese dub is not available due to licensing issue. Note that unofficial voice mod is available.
[b]X[/b] Require a second playthrough (in new game plus) if you want to get every collectible in game. New optional events in new game plus is extremely minor.

[h1]Remarks:[/h1]
[b]-[/b] While the English script is very well written, it is heavily localized (very liberal). Personally, I prefer a tad more literal (direct) translation. This is not a bad thing per se, especially when it is done by a trustworthy localization team like XSeed / Marvelous USA. If not handle properly, heavy localization can lead to translation errors, resulting in changes in character personalities and lost of original cultural references; [spoiler]I am looking at you Nintendo Treehouse![/spoiler]
[b]-[/b] While I enjoy every second of the game, its linear and slow story progression with lots of long text only scenes might not be everyone cup of tea.
[b]-[/b] This titile is intended to be a two part game, since it ended with a massive cliffhanger. Its direct sequel, The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel II, is not yet available on PC (currently available on Playstation 3 and Playstation Vita).

[h1]Conclusions:[/h1]
While it is definitely not for everyone, The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel is an extremely enjoyable, classic turn based JRPG with excellent story. Its direct sequal is already confirmed for PC port and currently in development. There are also sister games, The Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky trilogy, with the same setting (though at earlier timeline) available now on PC.

34675481.review:
I would easily describe this game in one word: FAN******TASTIC!

This game matches the quality set by the Sora no Kiseki (Trails in the Sky) series. Although this may be the first of another trilogy, this game does not let you down, especially at the end of the game where the dramatic experiences escalates tremendously... theeeeeeeen ends on an incredibly cruel cliffhanger that makes Trails in the Sky FC's seem rather tame. Unfortunately, we have to wait a while before getting the second act of this incredible journey on PC, so we might as well tide ourselves over with this gem.

Back to the synopsis; this game takes place in Erebonia, the country that has been notoriously discussed in the Sky series as a warmongering country, when in fact the truth is far more complex than it seems. You see how this country behaves through the time that Rean Schwarzer and the rest of Class VII spend over at Thors Military Academy. You get to observe how each character in Class VII progressively grows into the unique and fascinating inviduals that they are, as well learn where they stand with how Erebonia as a country runs.

One of the most interesting elements of the story is that it progresses over the course of a school year; each gameplay day represents a particular type of school day, such as Free Days, dungeon investigations, side quests for people at the academy and Trista, and of course the amazing Field Studies! Field Studies are the best parts of this game due to the fact that you travel to various parts of the country to learn about Erebonia's history, culture, and its people, furthering character development for all of Class VII!

Speaking of gameplay, I would argue that it is the best of the currently released PC Trails series, especially the combat. The combat is much faster than the Sky trilogy due to the Combat Links provided by the new ARCUS battle orbmants. With combat links, each character forms a bond with another to trigger an additional attack or effect depending on the bond level the characters have with one another. More combat link effects will unlock later in the game that will allow you to unleash devastating attacks on your opponents with satisfying flair. Oh the joy of seeing your party wipe the floor with your enemies!

If you are not aware, the Trails of Cold Steel series runs parallel with the Crossbell arc. Everything that is happening in Cold Steel is happening AT THE SAME TIME as Zero no Kiseki! You will see so many references to the Crossbell region that it makes you want Zero no Kiseki so badly to find out about the characters that are mentioned, as well as seeing just how exactly the story unfolds in tandem with Cold Steel. Who knows when we will get to see the parallels fully, but it is something to look forward to.

If you have not played a Legend of Heroes game, I would HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend you hold off on this game and go purchase and play the entirety of the Trails in the Sky trilogy; seriously, it is incredibly good and will help you more emotinally connect with the world of Zemuria even more, as well as care deeply about returning characters in Cold Steel, and go crazy when certain characters names are mentioned!

Once you do get the chance to play this wonderful first chapter in an epic new quadrilogy(?), I hope you enjoy this game as much as I have!

*NOTE: You will need to play this game twice in order to experience everything it has to offer. Be ready! :)

34673766.review:
Probably the best JRPG I've ever had the pleasure of playing in terms of character development, worldbuilding, story progression and so on. At first it seemed like everyone was a simple anime trope, but all the protagonists are complex characters with motivations and tastes and they interact with each other in very interesting ways.

Also, I love the fact the game actively encourages you to study the story of the world and other unrelated things(at one point I had to do a test on stuff like CPR and real-life military strategy) as it really adds to the immersion.
Everything is placed there for a purpose, even if that purpose is just to make the world feel enormous and complete.

The combat system is very confusing at first, and there's a few cheap tricks you can do to make it really easy(depending on the difficulty ofc) but it hasn't gotten boring yet for me, to the point I like to farm enemies just to collect their data sometimes. You have an overwhelming amount of customization for each character and you're also encouraged to use all of the characters of the cast despite only having 4(or 6 if you count subs) at a time in combat, because of story rotativity or just their different traits being interesting to explore.

Overall, I'd probably pay twice what I paid for this game had I known what I was getting into at the time.

34663404.review:
[h1] Note for newcomers to series [/h1]

First of all, if you are just checking out this game and have never heard of [b] The Legend of Heroes [/b] series, note that this is the 6th game in [b]The Legend of Heroes[/b] saga (first in this arc)
set on the continent Zemuria. The series currently consists of 3 arcs, each arc set in its own country. This is the latest (3rd) arc which is set in the country Erebonia, 
the previous (2nd) arc which is set in Crossbell runs simultaneously to this one, and as of the time of writing has not been officially localized (yet?). [b][u] If this is the first time seeing this series I would strongly recommend to consider playing 
the first arc (Liberl) first, as events in this game are directly based on stuff that has happened in the past. [/u][/b]
The first game can be found on steam [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/251150/The_Legend_of_Heroes_Trails_in_the_Sky/] click here [/url]

Even if you haven't played the first arc you can still enjoy and understand most of the story, but the interconnectedness of this series is one of its strongest points.

[h1] Story [/h1]

The game follows the students of the special class VII at the Thors Academy in Erebonia through the eyes of our protagonist Rean Schwarzer.
Class VII has a special curriculum that allows them to go on field trips throughout Erebonia. The game has a very Persona vibe.

Since this is the first game in the arc expect a lot of world building in this one, the story moves very slowly but it allows for you to learn about this country, its problems and its people.
For me one of the best things is the large amount of npc dialogue available in the game, after almost ever game event npc dialogue changes and if you have the time to listen the npc dialogue can even foreshadow some plot twists.
The strong point of this game and this series in general is the world building, npc's have their little side stories that you can follow throughout the game, if you only take the time to talk to them.
There is the butler that is searching for a missing woman, learning more about teachers and students through talking with their family members and most minor characters on the campus have their own little arcs that you can choose to enjoy.
If you've played the earlier games you might just meet a few npcs who have come to this country all the way from Liberl.

While the story is quite slow it ends on a high point and there might be a few twists and turns you won't see coming.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Very similar to earlier Legend of Heroes games, you have your familiar arts and crafts. Orbments have been simplified a bit, you no longer have to accumulate your sepiths to get arts.
They are now inherit to the orbments themselves. New also are the ARCUS units Class VII uses, it allows them to us a ``master quartz'' which gives special bonusses and spells.
Also new is the inclusion of ``combat links'' class members can assist each other when you hit the enemy weak points.
You can socialize with your class members to raise their link level on the free days (think Danganronpa's free time).

You'll be doing quests around the campus and on the field trip locations each month, many which are optional and some are hidden as well. Optional quests are pretty easy this time around but never did I feel that I didn't want to do any of them.

I played through the game on normal and never did I have a problem with the combat, it might've been a bit too easy as most monsters (and some bosses) can be killed with craft spam. I barely used arts, only for healing and speed boosts.

Playtime was 114 hours.

[h1] Side Activities [/h1]

There is cooking and fishing to enjoy, both are pretty easy to 100% but you might still want to use a walkthrough to make sure you don't miss anything, like the chapters of the new book Red Moon Rose.

[h1] Music [/h1]

The music is very good, like all Falcom games. Check [u][b][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YbXAqwxwamE] this [/url][/b][/u] track that plays during the opening and later in the game.

[h1] Port [/h1]

The pc port is very well done, I've had 60 fps throughout and the including of the turbo button is one of the best modern addition to jrpgs, as it allows to cut down on time spent walking around and combat. I did have two crashes (in 114 hours) towards the final chapter, but none were very major (thanks turbo button).

tl;dr Very good game, very good port, very good story, please play Legend of Heroes: Trails in the Sky before this at least

34647150.review: Trails of Cold Steel is like a PG-13 version of Game of Thrones. The story and characters are definitely the draw, the clash of ideals and politics of the country of Erebonia taking center stage. You play as Rean Schwarzer who is a new student at Thors Military Academy where he joins Class VII, the newly instated class which throws together members of both the noble and commoner social classes. As you can imagine this creates a bit of tension where the ideals of the students clash, but it's interesting to see how they get over their inhibition and prejudices as they learn more about one another. There's a lot of conspiracy and world building here. For my money it's the best JRPG of the last 15 years at least. On top of the great story you have one of the best soundtracks in gaming ever, and a fun, snappy combat system. If you're a classic JRPG fan you owe it to yourself to check out Trails of Cold Steel. It's available on PS3 and PS Vita as well as the PC, though PC is definitely the definitive version thanks to the option of sped up gameplay (turbo mode) beautiful upgraded graphics and additional voice acting where Rean doesn't stay oddly silent as everyone around him talks. Also, the voice acting is superb across the board.

34645221.review:
Trails of Cold Steel é o primeiro capitulo do arco de Erebonia, terceiro arco de historias que se passam no mundo de Zemuria, mesmo mundo da série “The Legend of Heroes Trails in the Sky”. Ele se passa cronologicamente após o arco de Liberl e simultaneamente ao arco de Crossbell.

Embora seja o sexto jogo do mundo de Zemuria, Trails of Cold Steel é um jogo perfeito para iniciantes na série. Com uma narrativa inicialmente cadenciada e meticulosa, o jogo se preocupa desde o início com a inclusão e instrução de novos jogadores no universo da série. Por sua vez, os veteranos são premiados com pontuais easter eggs e cameos. 
O game possui uma historia complexa cheia de conspirações e debates políticos focados principalmente no tema de classes sociais. O inicio cadenciado logo vai ganhando ritmo à medida que o plot vai avançando e se aproximando do final. Sua narrativa é recheada de plot twists do inicio ao fim.

Primeiro jogo 3D da série, o gameplay é um avanço em relação aos jogos anteriores, o sistema é por turnos, porem ágil. Das novidades, é introduzindo o sistema “Arcus”, sendo possível fazer links entre personagens e selecionar até 7 lutadores no time, sendo 4 no campo de batalha e 3 de suporte, havendo a possibilidade de substituí-los durante a luta a qualquer momento. Outra novidade é a possibilidade de poder executar ataques especiais e em equipe utilizando “brave points”.

Graficamente o jogo não se destaca em comparação aos os jogos da geração atual, entretanto isso é compensando por um worldbuilding imersivo. Os personagens principais são carismáticos e suas motivações são bem desenvolvidas dentro da trama do jogo; o mesmo pode ser dito dos NPCs, praticamente todos tem seu próprio arco dramático o qual pode ser aprofundado à medida que o jogador tenha curiosidade e disposição para explora-lo. Já as cidades e são grandes, ricas, cheias de conteúdo e side quests disponíveis.  

Destarte, há de se destacar o excepcional Port para PC/Steam feito pela Xseed. Poucos jogos foram tão bem tratados como este.

Em suma, Trails of Cold Steel é mais um excelente jogo da sempre competente Falcom. Contando ainda com uma bela trilha sonora, ele é um dos melhores JRPGs disponíveis no Steam. Perfeito para quem não conhece e quer iniciar a série, e um deleite para os fãs de velha data.

E que venham as continuações.

34644029.review:
Although perhaps this installment doesn't compare in its overall quality to classics such as Trails in the Sky, it does live up to the name of legend of heroes series, in terms of story and gameplay. 

The newest combat gameplay system does not deviate too much from the traditional gameplay, slightly tweaking certain aspects and adding a lot more collection elements. Storywise, I found this part of the narrative quite good. Told mainly from the perspectives of a group of Erebonian military students, the POV is full of energy. The cutscenes have also been updated into 3D CG, along with about 30-50% English dub, helping to bring more (narrative) details into world-buidling and story-telling. However, there are two major problems that marrs this game: 1. how conflicts are resolved can be quite naive to certain extent 2. the school life and political conflicts, which make up the majority of the story, do not blend well with the ancient artifact/snake society's conspiracy part of plot

Overall, this game is worth buying and it took for me about 40 - 50 hour to complete it on normal. I'd give it a score of 7.5/10. I won't be buying the cold steel 2 though because the story there seems quite weak.

34641808.review:
[h1]A TRUE MASTERPIECE![/h1]

What can you say about a game that exceeds your expectations on every level? 

If you are a fan of the Trails in the Sky trilogy then you are going to love this game. Take my word for it.

Have you not played any games from the series but you are a generic fan of anime/JRPG?  Then I say you should give it a try. Because Trails of Cold Steel  marks the start of a brand new story which adapts certain aspects from its predecessors but swings to a unique direction. Some background knowledge may increase the taste you take from the story but it is not a necessity. 

It has a fascinating story that deepens with every step you take.  You watch the story through the perspective of Rean Schwarzer, a junior student in Thor’s Military Academy.  Yet from the very start of the game you find yourself surrounded by a bunch of different characters, your classmates and instructors. Characters who have travelled from different parts of the Erebonian Empire.  

Each of these characters possess a different personality, an uninhibited view of the world they live in. That’s right! Those classmates not “your gang” who keep following you blindly in your self-proclaimed quest.  They have their own thoughts, feelings and remarks. While some of them are rather friendly and modest from the very start of the story; you will find some are quite cynical and rude, rather hotheaded and prickly, quite cold and reckless, irritatingly proud and serious, amusingly childish and immature or rather polite yet completely shrouded by mystery. Every character has their own past and secrets which you discover throughout the flow of the game. These secrets vary from small ones like favorite foods or childhood dreams to rather serious ones like real name or lineage of a character. And these details make you feel like you are surrounded by real people instead of an army of side-kicks.  Only after experiencing some serious bonding events they will start to open up to you and respect you.

While you are trying to get used to your new life in the military academy, a much thicker plot starts to unwind  in the background which contains components of an international crises, an ever-growing civil unrest  between different social classes, a dark organization with a mysterious agenda and an ancient fairy tale that starts to show signs of legitimacy. And each answer you get will only trigger more questions.  And get ready for some unforeseeable twists!

Apart from the fascinating story and fulfilling character development, Trails of Cold Steel also offers a vibrant atmosphere and a great soundtrack. The characters will travel to different points of a giant empire and each step of their journey will take place in a completely different setting  varying from the others with an authentic  NPCs and fitting background music. Unless you are rushing the game, try to talk to as many NPCs around as possible. The things you learn, or the items you acquire may surprise you. 

As a fellow RPG-gamer I give this game 10/10 and recommend it to every JRPG lover. And keep in mind that this game is only the first installment of a trilogy. Therefore do not expect to see an “end” yet. ;)

一直以来，我在steam买游戏都是等打折才买的。
但是！但是！这是我第一次用原价112买的！
就因为我是个轨迹饭！

画面：比起PS3好很多，PS3是720P、30帧。PC是1080P、60帧。而且人物动作更加流畅不像PS3有点僵硬。

音乐：Falcom的音乐你还质疑？不过治愈系的音乐没几首能深入人心

剧情：网上说剧情很差，我不觉得。挺好的。
一群学生到处旅游，顺便打怪找猫送快递。

语音和字幕：没有日文语音是因为falcom仅拥有PS上的日语版权，PC上出日语语音需要额外给钱（据说伊苏8会有日配）。字幕是因为Xseed是面向欧美的发行商，所以只有英文。PS繁中是索尼SIE代工的。[spoiler]毕竟索尼靠光盘挣钱[/spoiler]
鉴于空之轨迹FC，不知道又会不会坑爹般的修复[spoiler]“中国玩家可以使用汉化包的”[/spoiler]BUG

利：不用一边看回路一边看系统说明对导力魔法，省下不少时间。而且法师不用再为了火属性魔法带个加普攻攻击力的“攻击3”。
弊：原本空零碧中角色叼不叼就看谁单链最长，现在闪轨看谁链子最短，因为可以带上几个牙啊刃啊之类的增加STR。现在一个回路只有一个魔法，某些高级的可以2~3个魔法。

最后！！！
等我把全成就拿了，我一定会入闪之轨迹2的！！！

I need 《Trails of Cold Steel222222222222》！！！！！！！！！！！！！！！

34608532.review:
Definitely one of the best JRPG's out there. This game originally released for Playstation 3 and Playstation Vita in 2013, but XSEED did a really got job at improving graphics for PC version. If you are interested in a good story, great characters and good turn-based tactical JRPG - this is the one for you.

Pros:
- High quality PC port, no crashes, a lot of available video options and tweaks.
- A "Turbo System" which will speed up your game, when you press and hold a specific button. Very useful for grinding levels/items or traveling over long distances. Seriously, every game should include a button like that.
- Awesome story and main characters, most of them is not your-generic-anime-cliche-stereotype.
- Your choices actually do something, so you better read the books in-game or search answers @Google.
- Some boss battles may be hard at first, but there's a key to each one of them, either it's some status ailments(that will help you tremendiously) or magical attacks vulnerability and such. Limit Breaks (aka EX skills) do a decent amount of damage. There's a lot of possible characters/squad combination in this game.
- Character customization. There's a lot of passive/active skills that you can equip. You can get those from treasure chests, as monster drops or even craft them. 
- There's 50% more voice lines, compared to PS3/Vita versions and i would say english voiceover in this game is really great.
- There's a lot of optional quests and content, however, be aware that THOSE ARE EASILY MISSABLE! If you advance from June, 25 to June, 26 and did not finish all hidden or optional quests(related to June, 25), then you can't complete those until next playthrough. Hidden quests are never marked in your quest book and you must search for them manually.

Cons:
- Some people may not like the graphics, since the game is kinda old already.

TL;DR 9.5/10

34607655.review:
-História rica, cativante q faz vc querer saber o q vem a seguir
-Personagens carismáticos (e q faz vc se importar com eles) muito bem construídos cada um com sua própria história
-Personagem principal mais genérico impossível, o q não tira o seu brilho, pois acompanhar sua jornada foi incrível
-Sistema de batalha excelente (parecido com Grandia II)
-Socialização com os personagens (lembra um pouco Persona) através de [i]Bonding Points[/i], onde em um determinado dia do mês, vc recebe alguns desses pontos, geralmente são 3, ae vc os gasta com os personagens q estiverem disponíveis durante o dia pra vc se socializar com eles

E apesar de ser uma turma grande (vc faz parte da [i]Class VII[/i], onde vc estuda em uma academia militar) , o relacionamento entre eles, a história contada e outros aspectos dá de 10 a 0 na turma de Final Fantasy Type-0, onde lá não tem um foco nos personagens em si, aqui é bastante focado.

Apesar de se passar no msm universo, não é necessário jogar a trilogia Trails In The Sky para entender a história de Trails of Cold Steel.

E um final (típico de season finale de série de tv) q te deixar louco pra jogar a continuação (Prevista ainda pra esse ano na steam, e o terceiro jogo chegará em setembro no japão).

Enfim, excelente jogo pra quem curte um bom JRPG e uma densa história. E q venha TOCS2!!!!

HAving played both the console and now this PC version:

HOLY ****

For the game itself: it's excellent. Think Persona 3/4/5 but with less social links and more combat. It's got a lot of character interaction, an excellent story and world, and engaging combat system that makes the turn-based droll nonexistent.

10/10 would 100% everything all over again.
