Эта игра заслуживает высоких оценок. И хоть на первый взгляд кажется что сеттинг банальный школьно-японский, но серия Kiseki - это не очередная поделка, которых полно, а общепризнанная классика жанра JRPG. В игре такая же теплая атмосфера приключений как в серии Trails in the Sky, отличная музыка и шикарный визуальный стиль.

33978427.review: I may have not played the pc version for long, but I played the ps3 version for over 300 hours. So, this is one of my favorite of all time rpgs. First of all, if you like Trails In The Sky, (in my opinion) Trails of Cold Steel is better, so fans of In The Sky would love this series. It has one of the biggest replay values I have seen in an rpg. For one, you get to choose who to romance, which alters the ending and gives exclusive bonding events. In quite a few certain points in the game, you get to choose who to bring into your party, and depending on who you bring alters the diologue. Also, the friendship and romance options you pick transfer over to the new games, (2-3, for when they come to steam) giving new diologue and changed cutscenes only possible with the save data clear with the romance and friendship choices transferred over. Now for the gameplay---The gameplay is full 3D and enhances the gameplay of In The Sky further while adding new elements. Outside of combat, you walk around the areas, talking to npcs, doing side quests, bonding with classmates, and some mini games at certain points. The side quests unlike most rpgs actually enhance the story and feel relevent. If you dont know about Trails In The Sky and want to skip right to this series, then thats fine too. This has its own unique story and chars that arent in In The Sky. The books also tell about what generally happened in the In The Sky series, and on Cold Steel. It is turn based but its a unique style with its duo attacks and 4 person party attacks. The game starts off slow but give it some time, as it takes it slow on purpose to give excellent character depth and world building. 10/10 in my opinion.

33976583.review:
There is really only one thing you need to know. Elliot is an egg factory. Force him to make you egg omelettes. That is the true path to victory in this game. 

I've played the Vita and PS3 versions for a total of over 100 hours. Trails of Cold Steel is a satisfying RPG that takes place in the same world as Trails in the Sky though you absolutely do not have to play those games to understand this one. It excels at world building, a good yet sometimes cliche story, fun turn based combat with customization/builds and a great soundtrack.

33976557.review:
(Owner of the Original PS3 version). 
Trails of Cold Steel is another fantastic entry into the Legend of Heroes & Trails series, this time in the country of Erebonia which is often warmongering in the likes of Sky & Zero, it takes place at Thors Military academy, think Hogwarts but for the military (the staff are quirky enough). 

Rean Schwarzer is the main character and is kind of divisive in the community on his standing compared to the other protagonists, but when he shines he really does, and his VA Sean Chiplock is part of what sells it. 
The game is a JRPG in the long running Trails series, which all interconnect however this one is somewhat free from the other games despite still being interwoven so it might even be a good jumping on point (just make sure to play Sky after it). The game has more Persona like mechanics with bonding, but the battle system is your same turn based grid tactical combat (except in Cold Steel its super fast). 

Theres tons of wonderful characters, a brilliant musical score, and while it may start slow, the intrigue picks up and leads into the next games in the franchise. 

A hugely recommended title, it will keep you busy for hours on end. The PC port adds onto the visuals and fixes framerate issues and adds in more voiced segments so that’s always nice.

33976391.review:

33976281.review:
Trails of Cold Steel is a new addition to The Legend of Heroes series by Falcom. I played the original Japanese version of this game on PS Vita two and a half years ago, and I think it is a very brilliant JRPG in many aspects despite some minor flaws.

[h1]Pros[/h1]


+ World-building is extremely well done, just as what Falcom has done for the past games in the Trails series. NPC's dialogues change when story progresses and even after some side quests/stories end, which I believe most RPG's do not really care. This is a living world with tons of details.

+ There are many insteresting characters, and they develop as the story progresses. Every character in Rean's (the main character) class has interesting background story, motivations, and purposes they want to achieve. Rean might be an exception though because his development is mostly in the sequel.

+ Lots of Amazing music exist in this game. Falcom JDK is famous for its high-quality music production, and Trail of Cold Steel shows how good they are. I love the music when they go out of town into the roads, and the background music of the final labyrinth and battle.

+ Game mechanics are creative and fun to play. The Orbment (magic) system changes a lot from the last game in the series (The trail of the Blue), and I personally think it is good change. ARCUS Link is a new feature in the combat system that is well-designed.


[h1]Cons[/h1]

- The story is unfinished at the end of the game, and it is also a cliffhanger. Unfortunately the sequel (Trail of Cold Steel II) is not on Steam yet, and personally I would not call this sequel a very good sequel because some questions still remain unaswered in the sequel. Japanese version of Trail of Cold Steel III is coming out on Sep 29, and I will be able to give a good opinion of the series overall after I finish it.

- The friendship (relationship?) system is what feel a little uncomfortable about this game. These are side stories which you, as Rean, can trigger with your partners (usually one character per side story), and you deepen your relationship with him/her after you complete the side story. Sometimes side story with female partner has subtle romantic implications, and this makes me feel like I am playing a visual novel. Gladly there is balance of male and female characters so this did not affect my experience that much.

-  Falcom is not very good at Graphics and modeling, unfortunately. This game came out a few years ago, and I think the postures and actions of character models are not that satisfying. As you can see, this game has a very Anime-like drawing style, and some people might not like this style. The sequel improves a lot on this aspect though.


[h1]Not Sure About[/h1]


? Since this is a English-voiced version, so I do not know about English voice-acting until I play it. However, I heard there are a few thousand more lines that are voice-acted than original Japanese version.

? I heard the translation is very good becasue translators add more meaningful stuff to the text when they translate. I still need to confirm that myself.

EDIT: Port is amazing. I feel it is better than Atelier Sophie and Neptunia series.

For voice acting, most of the characters' voices is good, although I still prefer Japanese probably because I first played this game in Japanese. Thumbs up for Sara, Emma, and Towa's voice actresses.

[h1]Ending Notes[/h1]

This is a great JRPG you cannot miss if you like JRPG's. This video by Mother's Basement on Youtube might help you understand what I mean by "world-building".

[u]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TaN2G-AEd9Q[/u]

And WATCH OUT FOR SPOILERS: This is the official site of Trails of Cold Steel III if you are interested (I am so excited btw)
[u]https://www.falcom.com/sen3/[/u]

Thanks for reading my review.

33976181.review:
Welcome to "The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel" (ToCS)

My review is based on my PS3 experiences (Cleared ToCS I and II twice), early PC insights and my personal opinion about this game. 

[b][h1]Trails of Cold Steels:[/h1][/b]
-J-RPG 
-Turn-Based 
-Flexible skillsystem with a lot of strategy
-Not the hardest but really pleasant difficulty [Normal] 
  (Go hard if you would like more of a challenge) 

-Story rich (Can drag on a bit at the beginning but it's getting really epic and interesting once you are hooked)
-It's quite linear but you have time to discover various places and towns (You have your freedoms) 
-No prior knowledge needed (Trails in the Sky or the other titles - Just light references)
 
-Great and illustre characters and character development
-Motivating to deepen the bonds (Similar to Persona) 
-Almost every character (NPCs included) has his/her own story 

-A lot to do (amsuing sidequests, minigames, discovering and collecting various stuff)

-Average graphics in general
-A lot of love put into details, characters and environment 
-Graphics are still way better compared to PS3!
-A lot of improvements over the PS3 version like higher resolutions, higher frame rates (60 FPS), depth of field, shadows and so forth

-Really great OST which is underlining situations and the mood greatly (Still listening to them from time to time)

Playtime: Between at least 80 hours and 120+ (Average for my first time was around 110 - PS3)

-It's the first game of a trilogy 
-ToCS II will come later to PCs and ToCS III will release in Japan this year
 
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

[b] It's pretty difficult to recommend this to everyone depending on what you like...and if you have some experience from games like Trails in the Sky FC/SC/TC and Persona [/b]

[u]At best I would say it's a mix of the previous Trails in the Sky and "Persona" in general [/u]

-It's a mix because like in Persona you have your everyday school life and mysterious battles/characters
-You are deepening your bonds with the "main characters" and getting to know their personality. This depends on the time you are giving each of them individually (Pretty similar to Persona)

The rest of the game is how you know it from Trails in the Sky 
-A lot of text-based conversations with spoken dialogues (way above average RPGs)
-A lot of details put into the story, the chraracters, background information and collectibles
-A lot of different things to do (next to the main story) like fishing, playing cards, quests and so forth  


The basic story (without spoilers) is best explained in the short wikipedia description I'm quoting here:

[spoiler] "The game's plot is centered around the newly formed special class "Class VII" in Thors Military Academy, composed of both aristocrats and normal Erebonian citizens. Class VII is the only class in the entire academy that does not segregate the two different social classes.

The game follows Class VII throughout their school year, mainly around the times when Class VII receive special field training that takes them all over Erebonia. Throughout their training across Erebonia, Class VII matures and casts aside their preconceptions of the two social classes and witness first hand the reality of the empire; The power struggle between the aristocracy led by the four noble houses, and the working class reformists led by Iron Blood Chancellor Osborne which threatens to lead to a civil war." [/spoiler]

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

[b][h1] So who would I recommend it to?[/h1][/b]
=> People who like Persona and are into spending time to develop bonds with various characters
=> People who like to play turn-based games with deep strategy (You can abuse every system...)
=> People who are into longer games (Average time = 90-100+ hours)
=> People who are seaching for a great story where everything feels connected (Characters, Story, Backgrounds)
=> People who don't dislike certain clichés 

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++


POSSIBLE LIGHT SPOILERS! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! !

[spoiler] Some random notes at the end (Just for me or maybe you even like it => (My Personal opinion)

-Rean is a great chracter for me [Realistic - Intersting - Mysterious] 
-Rean is human/kind and may come across as your "typical" hero [He is not - but he tries]
-His schoolmates come from various societies and families
-They have all their traits and quirks 
-They don't get along too well at the beginning and even later
-Problems will arise among themselves
-They are at odds with themselves
-The different reasons for their behaviour/quirks are explained well and make them loveable 

-The battles are fun and interesting
-The characters for battle are changing depending on the school trips and where you are in the story
-Even if you are not leveling you don't have to fear to be underleveled and to grind endlessly because you are getting more EXP the lower your average level is compared to the current monsters you are fighting
-You are even getting less EXP when you are higher compared to the average level of the monsters you are fighting 

-It was a pleasure catching all kinds of fish (Fishing), to play Blade (Card Game), to collect certain books and read a novel from time to time and to get to know more about the society and the world around ToCS

-A lot of German words mixed into the game (I'm from Germany so it's quite funny how they use different terms)

-Fun scenes: School trips, schwimming, awkward/funny situations the characters are getting into, school festival... [/spoiler]

One of the best J-RPGs in recent years! ;o)

33975442.review:
I put many many hours into the PS VITA version of Trails of Cold Steel by XSeed when it originally came out in the UK last year. As a fellow player of the previous two Trails in the Sky games, prior knowledge is not nessicary in order to start this game. Those who have played the previous iterations will find a deeper meaning and some fun references through characters and mentions however, but nothing that will take awaty the experience for a newcomer. 

This game, while an engine at fault, suffered frame issues on the VITA so being able to play this in a better quality, not only 60 FPS appeased me to get it once again. Falcom themselves, the original developers of the game have something unique in the craft of their games in this series, as once finished, you'll be yearning for more. That being said, first installments to a new adventure are usually slower than most. However, unlike sky, Cold Steel has an argueably more hooking beginning.

The battle system is one of the most refined in the Trails series yet. We lose some features like Rush, but we also gain a different way to do battle in the way of Master Quartz, to furter augment the skillsets and stats of your characters and the ability to swap them lets you build your characters in interesting ways.

Overall, a highly recommended title. Please tell your friends so we might get Cold Steel 2 next.

10/10

I beat this game twice on the PS3, first on normal then on nightmare. It's a little slow in the beginning and even a little cliche, but it definitely is a slow-burn type of game that will reward your patience with amazing world-building, characters, story-line, gameplay and soundtrack! 
Moreover, since this game is now on the PC, it can run at a buttery-smooth 60FPS!!
Not only that, there are big graphical improvements to the PC port that are detailed in XSEED's most recent blogpost by XSEED's coder, Durante. 
It also has a lot more voiced lines for the main character and even some revoiced lines for the other characters. 
If you're new to the Trails series I highly recommend you play Trails in the Sky FC first, then its sequel Trails in the Sky SC.

To those who have played the previously-released titles already, please continue to support XSEED by purchasing more of their games!
 We're still missing the famous Crossbell Arc! Thanks XSEED and keep doing good work.

33974773.review:
Social relationships are important in the life of a teenager. They open up the way to new experiences, great memories, and unlock powerful combat techniques that can be used to take down monsters from the Dark Ages. At one of Erebonia's top military academies, young people from all walks of life come together to team up and show off their combat skills they've mastered in their brief time on the planet.

The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel is the first entry in a trilogy that is part of an even larger video game world. Play as a student who must grow his relationship with his fellow classmen in order to overcome challenges both mystical and political. Customize your skills with the Orbment and ARCUS systems, utilized advantageous positioning, and swap characters in and out in the middle of battle to adapt to changing scenarios. 

[h1]Story[/h1]

The writing of the game is something of a mixed bag. While the plot handles some deep and complex subject matters like political uprising, social class systems, and school dances, it's all bogged down by the subpar dialogue. Regardless of how many characters are in a scene, the game feels that every single one needs to voice their thoughts on the matter, no matter how innane or if it's already been said. After awhile, scenes feel bloated with unnecessary thoughts thrown out into the mix.

Characters start off two-dimensional and tropey, but through the course of the game they unfold into more layered people. They go from chariactures to characters. That's part of the overall theme of the game, too. That while things are presented in a rather black and white manner, clear lines of delineation made, the truth is more muddled than that. Your friends might be nobles, but there's usually some element that makes them outcasts within their own social circle. The same can be said of the commoners in your party.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The turn-based system in this game is immensely satisfying. Rather than all your characters standing in a row, you are free to move them across the battlefield, to reach enemies or allies or to avoid oncoming attacks. Movement can only be done on their turn, and moving uses up that turn, however. Think of it likes a "Tales" game, but far more limited. Attacks come in a few varieties (Attack, Craft Skill, and Arts) and you'll need all of them to overcome even basic monsters on the field. 

The battle can turn sour quickly, as enemies aren't afraid of hitting hard. Making use of link attacks and damage types will be necessary to avoid having your entire party faint before you even leave chapter 1. Links are formed by building up your relationship with characters outside of battle. Each day you have a limited amount of interactions you can make with friends, and there is always more friends than you can meet in one day, so manage your interactions wisely. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

PROS
+ Very enjoyable combat that is never too hard or too easy.
+ Familiar upgrade system (to anyone who's play FF7, at least).
+ Beautifully upgraded graphics that run at 60 fps.
+ Substantial plot and interesting developments therein.

CONS
- Tedious and redundant dialogue slows everything down to a crawl (even in turbo mode).
- Even though characters develop into more interesting people, the main character remains the dullest somehow.
- No Japanese voice cast.

[h1]To read the full review, please visit this [url=https://www.keengamer.com/article/16895_the-legend-of-heroes-trails-of-cold-steel-review-pc]link[/url].[/h1] Thank you!

39393623.review:
This game is fun, but like many JRPGS drags on a bit at the tail end. This game reminds me of "Persona Lite". There are bonding events with characters, but it's really mostly just dialogue, they try to incorporate the relationships into the combat system, but it's pretty weak. I would honestly hardly notice if I was using Lvl 1 bonded characters vs Max Lvl bonds. That's fine, I dont NEED that type of system to make a good game, but this game tries to implement it and comes up short. If you're going to have me talk to people under the pretense of growing relationships, there needs to be some tangible evidence of that. In this game, you get some extra dialogue and that's literally all there is + the Link EXP. For people who are REALLY into the whole anime thing, and mainly play these games for the narrative, that will be fine, but I personally look more for gameplay on top of story.

To get to the gameplay: this game's combat is actually quite fun. It's positionally based (even if the positioning can be relatively clunky) and there are AoE effects to consider as well as status effects and the like. Customizing your characters and which "quartz" (ability gems) they use is fun. Towards the end, however, it migrates into a bit of tedium as you are given party members largely at random, and you will likely find that the characters you've been investing in all game will be taken away from you for the final encounters and you will have to juggle Quartz between your active party members and there is no great intuitive way to do this quickly.

I will underline all of this by saying that this game was originally on PS Vita. This limitation shows through OFTEN. There is hardly any animation here. If you're looking for a cinematic experience, you are wholly looking in the wrong place. The visuals are basic, the characters are relatively basic, and the conflict is really the saving grace of the game. The storyline is strong enough to hold your interest, though the myriad of anime tropes and overdone exposition might turn you off.

yes. LIGHT SPOILER ALERT
[spoiler]
But this game WILL in the final chapters of the game, where the stakes are the highest, force your party to GIVE A HALF A FUCK about a god damn summer festival at school. I. Dont. Care. Why would my characters care about putting on a fucking concert for their classmates when theyre trying to prevent a war and have been facing a supernatural mansion every month for the past year.[/spoiler]

This type of stuff REALLY REALLY pulls you out of a game like this. I have to believe that this is true unless you are the most die hard of anime fan and you just absolutely can NOT get enough of the uncreative, overused tropes that they use. They are not even approached in any different way than usual. This will be a selling point for some, and an absolute turn off for everybody else.

All of that being said, I enjoyed the game, I will [b]HIGHLY RECOMMEND[/b] that you play on the absolute hardest difficulty from the start if you're looking for any kind of challenge or have played JRPGS before or you will quickly find out how to "Cheese" the enemies and bosses in this game, however if you play on nightmare, I can pretty much guarantee that the fights alone will make this game worth buying. Thats one of the major reasons I love JRPGS and I can tell you this game nails it. Status effects can actually effect bosses, and thats all I really need to say.

Overall; if you're a JRPG fan, get this. It's fun, plain and simple.

39392624.review:
买下这个游戏后，花了5，6天以简单难度通关，老实说感觉很差，可能是空轨在我心中地位比较高，所以要求比较严格。
1.首先在画质，图像上，感觉很差（可能是玩过巫师3之后眼光高了），相比原来的轨迹系列，除了有大腿、屁股可以看这一点占优以外，其他没有什么。想当初SC尤莉亚上尉和卡西乌斯对练的那段剧情我一直很喜欢，时不时的读档回去看，而本作一有什么大动作要不就是一闪而过，要不就是眼前一黑。完全没有做出3D应有的特色，那还不如做回2D，省下经费完善其他的内容。
2.其次，战斗系统依旧是原来的AT战斗系统，很有特色我也很喜欢，但是为什么要把导力回路系统换成现在这样？原来虽然会花大量的时间去配魔法，或者专门为了一个某场战斗去配回路，但这难道不是这个游戏的特色所在？也许这么做是方便新玩家入坑，但是我现在不想继续进坑了（接下来会解释）。
3.接下来说剧情方面。说实话剧情没有让我玩下去的动力，剧情十分的拖沓，作为轨迹老玩家，我最在意的就是还没有出现的5个至宝和结社的幻焰计划，结果本作花了大篇幅讲贵族派和革新派的矛盾（明明可以让他作为支线让玩家慢慢来了解，非要硬生生的设置成主线），惬意的校园生活，本想着结尾会有点什么期待或者惊喜，结果发现好大一坨惊喜等着你吃（明摆着让你继续玩下一部）（相比FC的结尾就算不继续玩SC也不会觉得有多大损失，比较完美的结尾）。再说说本作的幕后黑手《C》，身份表明得毫无预兆，让人觉得很突兀，就凭最后那几个人的推断，莫名其妙的就让一个人变成反派了？（相比FC的几个主谋：约修亚见到怀斯曼的时候身体会有反应;理查德是一步步调查出来的）。
4.人物塑造方面，我个人很不喜欢这种塑造方式（听说闪二比这个还差）。空轨系列的人物的性格等方面都和她的经历有关，换句话说他的经历影响着他现在的性格，经历的表述过程也很自然，这种方式也更能让玩家记住这个角色。而本作的人物塑造简直一塌糊涂，疯狂埋伏笔，生怕你不想知道知道这个人经历了什么，甚至有时候当我了解到一个角色的经历的时候，我内心没有任何波动，还有点想笑。可以说完全没有感染力。让人最气的就是班长艾玛，人物伏笔埋得最多的就是她，到后面看到她又埋伏笔就来气（不说就不说，哪来的这么矫情的人），玩通关之后都不知道她是干什么的就更气了。
5.最后说说我不想玩下一部的理由吧，各方面都不如前作算是一部分理由吧，不过这都不算什么。最让我不想继续玩下去的是对接下来剧情的失望。首先，本作最后是用高达（暂且这么叫吧）来战斗，写测评之前也稍微看了看其他的测评，其中也有部分闪二的，从中了解到其大部分战斗也是动不动就叫高达，让我很失望，从空轨开始一路棍子、刀子、手弩、拐棍打上来，看的是一个角色心智、武力的成长，一个个都开机甲了，那还修炼什么啊，学什么武术啊，学开高达算了。

39392390.review:
Well after 120 hours of game-play I've finally beaten The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel.  I think as a whole it's a really good RPG, it does have some flaws; foremost is the FFX/FFXIII corridor layout  of maps/dungeons.  This is not a game where you're going to be able to wander about, every map is simply Point A to Point B and if there is any side areas, it's only to hide away a treasure chest or boss.  Now given how most of the game is mission based and you can fast travel to most places, you never really get the feeling of running back and forth over the same map continuously.

This leads to the other major issue: Not being able to go back to locations from previous chapters.  You're introduced to various towns and  locales, all populated with interesting characters and countless amounts of dialogue.   But once you've beaten a chapter in the game you never go back, which kind of hurts the chance for more interactions.  Maybe because this is the first in a trilogy they want to keep from over-exposing people and places and we'll get more of them later, but it does seem like a waste from a stand-alone game perspective.

And that's the final gripe right there:  This game really feels like part one of a series.  The big plot hook comes at the last part of the game, you basically get two big fights and then it's see you next time Space Cowboy.  Now that's not to say there haven't been plenty of other games that were part of planned series where that wasn't an issue; it's just you get cliffhanged so badly it kind of ends the game on a bit of a downer.

So with all those gripes out of the way THIS GAME IS REALLY ENJOYABLE.  This game's strengths is the depth given to all of it's characters.  The main characters start out very basic, but as the game progresses so do the characters and by the end of the game you find yourself attached to all the members of Class VII.  What's even more impressive is that effort was also put into the NPCs.  That's right the usual cardboard cut-outs that say things like "I like swords" get their own growth throughout the game.  Off the top of my head the feud between to business-minded students is a blast as you watch them try to one up each other throughout the game.  It's not like they play a major part in anything, yet they still get their own character arc.  For the first time I found myself talking to everyone to see what new little tidbits or quirky characters I might find.

The combat was also enjoyable.  It was turn-based with an order turn, allowing more strategy in interrupting/stun locking opponents to get through combat unscathed.  Also you get XP bonuses for identifying mobs/multi kills/ending battles fast, so if you do more then just press attack you can find yourself racking up the XP.  And achieving that is simple with Orbment skill system the game has.  Think of it as FFX's sphere grid, but where you get to choose what skills/stat buffs you want for each slot; though some slots require a certain element.  The added benefit is that there is no real class system, so you can simply take the characters you like and make them whatever class of character you want.  It helps to reduce the feelinggy of being stuck with an annoying character because they're they only one of a certain class you have.

So yeah in the end this game was really fun, it's one I want to eventually go back and try to get some of the stuff I missed and to get better bonuses for when Part 2 comes out; which is a rare case for me (the Mass Effect trilogy were the last ones where I went back and played multiple times for stuff).  If you're looking for a RPG with some real meat on it in terms of characters and world building, this is the game.

39248577.review:
I can't believe I have almost 30 hours in this game. About 10 of those hours are actual gameplay, the rest is meaningless chit chat. I have played games with a lot of dialogue and enjoyed them but this one just doesn't hold your interest. You can only talk to someone about their limited edition stickers for so long before you want to pull your hair out. 

You can't sort items in your inventory, if you read a magazine you get kicked out of your inventory so you have to go all the way back in and search for it and then if you accidently click on a book you have read it pops up 'You read this already' and kicks you out. There is no comparison between weapons in the shop so you can't gauge the difference between what you have equipped and what you want to buy. You have a very, VERY limited amount of equipment you can find/buy anyway. 

At the academy you run around playing errand boy to students, eventually you just can't be bothered anymore and just want to get on with the game. You then go from the academy to your field study, the field studies are fun it is where you get some actual gameplay in and solve a mystery or two. The battles are also interesting and I feel they definitely require you to think more than a lot of older rpg's do.

I was expecting a game similar to LOH: Trails in the sky and this was nowhere near that calibre. Although not a bad game, I find myself using turbo to avoid the drabble and to especially to avoid Rean's buttkissing.  I hope I am close to the end because I can't take much more.

39247677.review:
As a warm afternoon sun shone over the beautiful town square, I took a moment to breathe in the smell of cherry blossom as a pert blonde stepped out from the station door behind me. I was startled as she bumped into me, falling to the floor with a cry of 'oh!', but like a perfect gentleman I helped her up and apologised. Cherry blossoms swirled behind me as I did so.

By pure coincidence, she happened to be wearing the same red school uniform as I; we didn't know what the uniform signified, but had shown up to our first day of elite high school education and were excited to find out. The buxom, red-eyed blonde laughed hollowly and ran off screen, as my character, the dashing Rean Schwarzer, clapped a hand to my head and exclaimed 'I forgot to ask her name!'

Although it's visually fairly charming and the combat system seemed promising, it was at this point that I decided the game was not for me.

Challenging boss battles and battle system that never felt old or stale even up till the last dungeon. Every character was memorable and cant wait to see where the story will go in the next game.

Only thing I didnt like after about 50 hours was the music.... easlily fixed with turning off BGM (background music) and putting on some youtube tunes.

Ready to throw my wallet at the Cold Steel 2 when it comes out early 2018. If you are looking for a rpg to keep engaged and entertained for the next 80-100 hours with a thrilling story and plot twist and turns, then your have found your next game. 10/10 in my opinion.

39222620.review:
It's impossible to hide the fact that this game takes a while to get going; it is, after all, the first part of 4 parts of a story, set a couple of years after a three-part game and happening alongside a two-part game, each part taking between 40 and 60 hours. There's a lot to take in and a lot will happen and you won't have answers to every question you'll have by the end of this part, but you will surely be left expecting the next part with joy, not anger at unsolved threads.

With that out of the way;

fans of the Trails in the Sky trilogy already have some idea of how this game works; for others, it's simple; it's a very long JRPG with strategic combat, a frankly gigantic amount of sidequests and well-written characters, all accompanied by some fantastic music. While some may not appreciate the school setting or the format where the game constantly locks the door behind you after each area you complete, this at no point feels restraining of the type of story they want to tell; yes, it's about friendship and the general "finding your purpose in life" journey so often seem, but then there's cutthroat politics and more.

Every character early on seems to fit on a certain anime stereotype, but as you progress, you find the depth that every - well, amost every - character has; it may take a while however, as the game takes its time to pick up the pace; when finally does, you'll be in for quite a ride.

39130494.review:
If you're a fan of JRPG's or story-rich games in general, I can't recommend this title enough.

Graphically it's nice for the type of game, though it won't compare to anything on a par with the more recent final fantasy games, but that much is a given really, as is clearly visible in the screenshots and, as this is an RPG to begin with graphics are pretty much at the lower end of the important features.

The characters are irritating early on, but they quickly grow from annoying to likeable characters.  The voice acting for the most part is excellent, though there are a few moments where some characters, such as one of the characters parents, sounds rather mechanical in her responses, but that may be intentional as you will understand when you meet her.

The combat - It's pretty standard for JRPG's in that it's turn based with the usual types of attacks with slightly different names.  If you've played the other Legend of Heroes series (Trails in the Sky) then it's pretty much identical.  It's also a follow on of the story from that series, so it's worth checking that series out as well!

Don't get me wrong, there are some infuriatingly cheap moments that come with extremely bad luck, such as losing 2-3 party members to one deathblow attack because the numbers stacked against you, but when you learn how the system works it becomes far less of a problem, after which only 2-3 fights gave me any real problems.

I won't say the combat doesn't get a bit repetitive, but the endearing characters and the decent story more than make up for it.

So, that's the basics...  As for the most important part, the story:

I was quite surprised to be perfectly honest.  When the game started, despite seeing the reviews raving about it, my first thought was "Urgh...  It's going to be another trope-fest", but as the story progressed each chapter found something new that either took me completely by surprise, or egged you on with juuuuuuuust enough information about one of the characters that meant you just wanted to keep playing.

The only warning I will give is (and I'll use spoiler notice here, although it's not a direct spoiler it is regarding the ending of the game, without giving any story etc away) [spoiler] that there are 2 games to the series and as a result, it ends on possibly one of the worst cliffhangers I have experienced, be it in game, film 'or' TV series.  And that includes cliffhangers between some episodes of TV shows, not even season finale's...

The next game in the in the series 'is' apparently being worked on, but most information I can find on it seems to indicate that it isn't going to be at least until the end of 2018 before it's released...  Hopefully it will be before then, but I am not going to hold my breath... [/spoiler]

39093113.review:
So, this is my first review, and I had to write it because this game is FANTASTIC. I am a huge fan of JRPG's, it's what I grew up on, and still continue to play to this day. Tales of Vesperia is my favorite JRPG of all time, but Legend of Heroes has taken a firm number two spot. 

What the game does right: 
Characters - The characters are diverse and well written. I find myself liking a majority of the characters they introduce, and find myself LOVING a select few. Very few characters are poorly written, and although you may hate a few characters in the beginning, the more you learn about them, the more you understand. With 9 main characters, they do a great job of talking about all of them and showing the type of person they are. 

Story - Super enthralling. I played 12 hours straight my first night with this game. I couldn't put it down because I had to keep playing

Music - OH THIS SOUNDTRACK. It's incredible, so pleaseeeeeee play with volume up and don't have anything in the background 

Combat - Incredible single-player JRPG strategy combat. I think its unique and enjoyable. 

Things this game does wrong: 
Traveling - Sadly, this game puts HUGE restrictions on traveling, limiting you to small areas for quite a while, and keeping you stuck in that one area until you finish your job. 

Quests - The quests ALWAYS end the same way for each zone, which leads to a lack on unique gameplay and a predictable ending to the chapter. 

Overall, 9/10. Buy this game on sale or full price, it is worth it no matter what,

39003638.review:
This game is so amazing I legit feel guilty for buying during the winter sale. Absolutely worth price.

I'll start off with the good then hit up the couple of slightly more annoying bits at the end

***Worth noting that this game is a slower paced STORY/LORE heavy RPG, do not expect action 24/7 with this game. Lots of character development and world building. This game will probably take 70-80 hours to beat.***

The good:

-The amount of effort that must have gone in to giving every single NPC new locations and new dialogue during every single transition from morning to noon to night must have been staggering. No NPC will ever tell you the same thing twice if the time of day has changed. From the annoying Patrick Hyarms to the janitor. They all move throughout the day with new lines each and every time. Makes talking to NPC's in the game amazing. (Talk to Beryl or vivi whenever you can for good laughs.)

-World building is nuts as well in this game. Every chapter you visit a new location and find out more and more about political climate of the hot mess of a country that is Erebonia. The zones themselves range from snoozer to oh shit I wouldn't mind living here. Nord is gorgeous with great music, legram is hauntingly beautiful little town.

-The ending. Yeah thats right. I'm putting this under good. I won't spoil anything. But anyone who Played FC and had to wait for SC knows exactly what kind of cliffhanger falcom like to give it's fans. If you end the game with anything other then "WHERE THE FUCK IS THE REST OF THIS GAME" you're weird. but its in a good way. You will spend the next 3 days of your life googling "WHEN DOES TRAILS OF COLD STEEL 2 RELEASE ON PC" in all caps, of course. Love you folks at XSEED!

-So many other good points to this game. It's a slow burner. Don't rush things even when you get impatient, you will cheat yourselves out of so many little breadcrumbs. Take your time and enjoy the ride. It's worth it.

The barely bad:

-Voiced parts of the game can be a bit patchy at times. One scene will be fully voiced followed by the next being not. Not too big a deal though and takes very little away from an otherwise amazing game. 

-The way they handle character movement during cutscenes can be a little underwhelming at times. Outside of a few headpats and a couple other instances, everyone stands the same or poses the same during scenes making things feel a little robotic at times. I will say you will only notice this for the first few hours or so before you get used to it and no longer care. Given the enormity of the game and the smallish size of the company that makes the game however this totally gets a pass in my book.

38964999.review:
[h1]前言[/h1]
《闪之轨迹1》是经典JRPG轨迹系列的第六作。轨迹系列做为传统JRPG,拥有着庞大的世界观和丰富的剧情，但和很多JRPG不同的一个特点是，轨迹系列给人的感觉是多了一丝温情，还有更贴近日常生活。一个好的故事需要有合理的矛盾和冲突，其中“矛盾”是广义的，人与人之间的矛盾或者角色内心的矛盾等，都是推进剧情所必须的。而轨迹系列当然也拥有矛盾与冲突，比如贯穿整个系列的庞大计划以及国家之间的斗争等，加上愈发庞大的故事线以及安排合理的剧本，让游戏的剧情完全有条件成为一个好故事。轨迹系列的受众范围是面向全年龄的，游戏中的人物，不论是主角、还是路人，甚至是反派，大多都给人一种友善的感觉，你会发现几乎没有那种坏得彻底的坏人。而在战斗方面，人与人之间的战斗最严重的就是打晕对方，除了剧情杀基本没有会死人的情况。而这样的设定可能会让人感觉太偏理想化，但这正是架空世界的魅力，只有在游戏中我们才能体验到这样想象中的偏美好的世界。
[b] 评测：[/b]
[h1]世界观[/h1]
《闪之轨迹》传承了前作庞大的世界观。轨迹系列描绘的是一个科技与魔法并存的奇幻大陆，有着越来越先进的科技，但同时也有科学无法解释的强大力量和各种各样的怪物，并且拥有着宗教信仰，人们都信奉空之女神。科技以一种名为导力的技术为基础，从电脑到交通工具再到武器，通通用导力解决。而魔法则以七种属性为主。大陆上有众多国家和自治州，国家之间互相博弈，随着科技的迅速发展，世界格局也发生着巨大变化。《闪之轨迹》故事的主舞台发生在埃雷波尼亚帝国，是大陆上最强大的国家之一，随着科技产业的发展，帝国新兴的资产阶级平民阶层与旧贵族阶层之间的矛盾冲突是闪轨剧情的主要推动因素之一，主角们以学生的身份，在帝国各地实习的过程中发现这种矛盾冲突，并伴随着自身成长探寻出自己要走的道路。
[h1]剧情[/h1]
剧情的话为了不剧透就客观分析下吧。本作剧情核心元素和前作相通，主要讲述的是主角们不断成长，培养羁绊，并积极努力克服困难的故事。主角们会面对各种各样的任务和挑战，小到帮人找猫(这也是系列的一个梗233)、送快递，大到帮助对付恐怖分子、解决涉及到国家的问题等。《闪之轨迹1》的剧情相比于前作，略显平淡，没有太多高潮，很多地方都是在做铺垫。主角们的身份是军官学院的学生，故事则围绕学校的学习生活和外出实习展开。个人认为本作剧情还是很不错的。
[spoiler]很多玩过前作的人觉得闪轨不好，怎么说呢，见仁见智吧。[/spoiler]
[h1]《闪之轨迹》的改变[/h1]
和最早的《空之轨迹》相比，不说剧情，《闪之轨迹》在设定上还是有很多变化的。最明显的一点体现在游戏中加入的一些元素，校园、后宫、百合、妹控等等，在游戏中也加入了羁绊系统，会有特殊的羁绊剧情。这种转变算是迎合如今消费者的口味，但也侧面反映了如今JRPG的衰落。
[h1]游戏性[/h1]
我是剧情向玩家，难度基本都选普通，关于战斗可能理解不是特别深。轨迹系列的战斗是回合制，每作在一些细节上可能有所不同，但大体还是一样的。说起回合制很多人都会望而却步，其实我也不是很喜欢回合制，不过轨迹系列的回合制是比较有趣的，属于战旗类的回合制，战斗场地有范围，而人物也有移动范围、攻击范围、魔法战技施放范围。角色拥有很多属性，比如基础的攻击防御速度等，而装备方面主要就是针对各项属性进行提升，所以游戏的装备系统比较简单。而丰富游戏战斗的是魔法和战技。魔法根据玩家自己通过选择不同的结晶回路来搭配，闪轨在这方面省去了前作配魔法的设定(这个比较难解释，总之就是简化了很多)。战技则是每个角色特有的，每个角色都拥有强大的S战技。魔法和战技的合理运用是战斗的核心，对于喜欢战斗的玩家还是比较有意思的。
ps:战斗系统还是比较复杂的，可能解释不太清楚。
[h1]音乐[/h1]
轨迹系列的音乐我最喜欢的一点是和游戏的契合性，例如在战斗时表现出的燃，在日常时表现出的安静欢快。《闪之轨迹》在音乐方面同样很出色，不论OP、ED还是各种场景的BGM，都有极强的代入感。可以说音乐是这个系列最优秀的方面之一。
[b]本作个人喜欢的几点：[/b]
[h1]日常[/h1]
游戏的日常剧情方面带我非常喜欢。在游戏中，除了主要的人物们。不论主角们周围的同学还是城市里的每个人，都有属于自己的故事。随着剧情推进与他们对话会逐渐了解他们，知道他们的日常生活和喜怒哀乐。平淡的日常往往也会带给人意想不到的感动。
[h1]主角[/h1]
闪轨系列的主角黎恩是我最喜欢的人物之一。和前作的主角们相比，命运可谓是跌宕起伏，不过这里说太多了怕剧透。作为主角他实力上很有潜力，与人相处时表现出的是一种亲和力和领导力，常常作为班级中领导者和协调者。自身性格方面，黎恩给人的感觉是温柔友善、正直勇敢、意志坚强。面对别人的误解和挑衅他会选择接受，并努力解决，总结一下就是以德报怨。当同伴面对危险时，他会毫不犹豫挡在前边。但他的缺点和弱点也很明显，那就是他内心的迷茫。[spoiler]大概就这样，再说可能剧透了。=-=[/spoiler]
[h1]校园剧情[/h1]
校园剧情我还是很喜欢的，闪轨在这方面可能做得不是特别好吧，但我觉得还是不错的。
[h1]总结[/h1]
关于这篇评测我觉得自己是写不好的，因为我太喜欢这部作品了，对于一些缺点我都不能指出，所以也不评分了。不过闪轨1不和前作相比，单独作为一部作品的话，除了结局部分的突兀，剧情整体上是没什么问题的。我很推荐这部作品，当然也想安利整个系列。期待闪轨2早日登录steam，也期待闪3中文和闪TLS（4）！
最后感谢朋友的礼物！❤

38959349.review: Amazing RPG... One of the best I've played. Unfortunately, it ends on a bit of a cliffhanger. I can't wait for the next installment!

38955615.review:
I went into The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel without expectations, and left with it as one of my favorite games of all time. This game sucked me in and didn't let go for over 80 hours. I've never really clicked with a JRPG before, though I am a pretty avid anime/manga fan, so finally finding my game in the genre is amazing.

Frankly speaking, The Legend of Heroes: Trails of Cold Steel is a steal at $40, the sheer volume of quality gameplay and story you're getting for your money blows most Western RPGs out of the water. It isn't an amazing looking game (it was originally made for the PS3 and PS Vita, after all), but the graphics are consistent and the game runs at a buttery-smooth 60 FPS.

The plot slowly unfurls to reveal one of the most intriguing video game storylines I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The characters are all memorable and rapidly endear themselves to the player, while shadowy political entities duke it out behind the scenes and create more than a little mystery. There are two other released Trails of Cold Steel games that are direct sequels to this, and another one is on the way - II should be on Steam by mid-2018, while III may take much longer; IV will release in Japan in Fall 2018 so that game may not show up in the West until 2020. You should be prepared for the long haul with this series.

38950775.review:
This is the first time that I play a jrpg by Falcom so I can assure you that you don't need to play the other The Legend of Heroes to enjoy this. Sure, there are references to the Trails in the Sky series but that's not a big deal and I understood, more or less, what they refers to.

[h1]Story[/h1]
I can't say so much about the plot so far. It's very cliché and japanese-style. Also it's setted in a military academy so it's politic-centered, otherwise Cold Steel has the usual high school stuff like your average anime. There's also a lot (A LOT) of lore so it's difficult to understand everything on the first hours but you'll eventually take the grasp of that. I don't want to write other things because I don't want to make spoilers. I'll only say that the ending is full of plot twist followed by other incredible plot twists. I usually hate plot twist but those were breathtaking and lastly there's a huge cliffhanger that I hated, but also loved.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Pretty solid stuff I'd say. The game has good mechanics, taken from various jrpg (for the battles) and from Persona (for the school life). Unfortunately Persona is way better in this kind of things but Trails of Cold Steel is still fun and enjoyable. In the long run I eventually got bored only by the many NPCs because I wanted to talk with everyone and their dialogues often change after every stupid event. Thumbs up for the rest.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
It's not that good but it's a porting so it's natural. At the first glance is nice and catchy but it's not difficult to see that the environment is empy and with low quality textures.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Very good and orchestrated in general. 2 or 3 bgm (Atrocious Raid for example) are simply marvelous and addicting. 

[h1]Characters[/h1]
This is the worst thing about the game because there not a single interesting character. I love Fie, Jusis and Crow for example but they are barely good enough. The others (Gaius, for example) are so plain that it is actually sad. I have seen characters like these in hundreds of anime and games and they are usually used as secondary characters lel.

[h1]Longevity[/h1]
Ok I'm a slow player but it took me 120 hours to finish this game. I red in Howlongtobeat that the average is about 80 hours (60 for the story) but I can't understand how is that even possible. Probably I lost time talking to every single NPC 2-3 times after every event. And as you can see I still miss lots of achievements. So I don't think anyone could complain about this. Usually you don't even play jrpg if you don't like long games.

[h1]Porting[/h1]
*Clap clap clap*
Good job for this porting. It's very solid and the settings in the game folder are extremely precise, it started to lag only in the final part of the game because of the crowd of people. And I only have an humble laptop.

So... what else can I say? Good title but nothing outstanding. I'll gladly wait for the incoming second game.
